title: celebrations-as-prestonpans-charity-elcap-marks-its-30th-birthday
story: The Lighthouse Hub hosted the event with a buffet, guest speakers and local musicians.Even microphone problems and a broken slideshow couldnrsquot dampen the mood as the birthday bash opened with two pipers from Preston Lodge High School Pipe Band.Bette Francis, member of the ELCAP board, hosted the event, introducing the speakers: chief executive Paul White, ward councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell, and lastly a moving testimony from fellow board member Kirstin Doherty.Paul White, who was appointed chief executive five months ago, started the talks by outlining the importance that ELCAP played within communities, a point that was reiterated by guest speaker Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell.The final speaker, Kirstin Doherty, a member of the ELCAP board, has been supported by the charity since . Her speech closed off the formal side of the event and she outlined how ELCAP had helped her move out of her parentsrsquo house, go on holiday and gain more independence.ldquoThey have helped me achieve more than I ever thought possible, she concluded.Kirstin, along with Ms OrsquoDonnell and Bette Francis, then proceeded to cut the cake to a chorus of lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo from the guests.Attending the event was Linda Headland, the first chief executive of ELCAP in , a position she held until .ldquoItrsquos always good to know that you can leave something in good hands, she said.ldquoWhen ELCAP started, we always believed that it was about giving people a le, not just an existence, and that still stands to this day.ldquoItrsquos all about finding new ways to bring people in to the community.The charity, which is based in Prestonpans, will be hosting two other events this year to celebrate its th birthday, including one in June at the Scottish Parliament.

title: east-lothian-council-lar-housing-rejected
story: Housing charity LAR had applied to build four houses and  flats on the land, which is designated for business use, in Prestonpans but has failed to find an employer to take it on.Despite a personal plea from the charityrsquos chief executive and an admission that East Lothian Council had tried to buy the site for housing itself just two years ago, the affordable housing bid was rejected at a meeting of the councilrsquos planning committee on Tuesday.The decision came despite LAR revealing it had invested pound, in preparing plans for the site after it was told the council would consider a change of use.Chief executive Ann Leslie told the committee that out of  homes built or under construction by the charity since it began,  had been in East Lothian and there were currently  people on its waiting list to move into one in the county.And she revealed the charity has been considering moving its base to East Lothian.She said: ldquoWe are very keen to support East Lothian as much as we are able to bring as many affordable homes as we can. There is a big waiting list in the county and we hope to open a base here.But planning officers urged councillors to reject LARrsquos proposals, regardless of their own efforts to build housing there two years ago.Iain McFarlane, head of planning, said that two years ago the council did not have its Local Development Plan approved and faced a shortage of land for affordable housing.Now the plan had been adopted, he said there was sufficient land supply for the next five years.He said allowing housing on the site would set an ldquoundesirable precedent, adding it would be ldquoselling our employment plans down the river.Councillor Kenny McLeod, committee member, said he was ldquodeeply uncomfortable about refusing planning permission on a site the council had tried to develop in the same way two years ago.At the time, council officers said the landowner rejected their pound, offer as too low.Robin Holder, representing LAR at the meeting, said the council had given written reassurance it would consider the site, which has lain empty since , for housing.He rejected claims that approving the plans would set a precedent, saying: ldquoThis is a small area, this site is a quarter of one per cent of land identied for industrial use in East Lothian. The site has been vacant for many years and the evidence suggests it will remain so.But Councillor Norman Hampshire said: ldquoI cannot support the application: it would send a message to other owners of land designated for business use.The committee rejected the planning application by six votes to three.Following the meeting, Ms Leslie said: ldquoNaturally we are disappointed at the decision and are considering whether to appeal against it.ldquoWe have worked very closely with East Lothian Council over the last three years on a number of projects to enhance the provision of good-quality affordable homes in the area and have enjoyed a very positive working relationship with them.ldquoOur proposal for Prestonpans was a design and build project for  homes, very similar to our recently completed development at the disused site of the former boatyard in Cockenzie. This proved to be extremely popular and was vastly oversubscribed, so there is an urgent need for homes like ours.ldquoWe understand that this site in Prestonpans had been earmarked for commercial use but, in the absence of any confirmed interest, we had hoped that our plans, which would enhance the local environment and provide much-needed affordable housing, would have been supported.

title: woman-was-five-and-a-half-times-over-drink-drive-limit-in-prestonpans
story: Gayle Duffy has been banned for  months after she was caught with mcg of alcohol in ml of breath at High Street, Prestonpans.The legal limit is just mcg.Duffy, of Clark Avenue, was also sentenced to a -day restriction of liberty order meaning she must stay within her home address between pm and am for the duration of the order.The -year-old had previously admitted the offence and she was sentenced at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Wednesday.Duffy admitted drink-driving on February .

title: asbo-bans-musselburgh-woman-from-abusive-behaviour
story: The ASBO was granted against Vivienne Stewart, , of Stoneybank Gardens South, following an application to Edinburgh Sherf Court by East Lothian Council.The court was presented with details of the alleged anti-social behaviour of Ms Stewart, which included shouting and swearing, excessive noise and reports of late-night disturbances.The terms of the ASBO ban her from behaving in a way that causes or is likely to cause alarm or distress to others, including playing a radio, TV or other sound-producing devices at anti-social levels, as well as shouting, swearing or using threatening, intimidating, aggressive or abusive language or behaviour within her home.A council spokesperson said: ldquoEast Lothian Council, with the support of Police Scotland, will not hesitate in taking robust action against those whose behaviour causes alarm and distress to others.

title: msp-hopeful-of-vastly-improved-service-at-musselburgh-gp-surgery
story: The group was highlighted by Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, who recently met Jeane Freeman MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport, following ldquooverwhelming public concern regarding the serious lack of appointments to see a doctor and the poor level of service offered by the practice.Mr Beattie stated that a spokesperson from the medical practice, which is based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, indicated that ldquoimprovements in the way patients are being cared for in Musselburgh are in the process of being made.Early evaluation of the way services were being delivered since the launch of the Collaborative Working for Immediate Care service ndash run by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershipand the merged Eskbridge and Riverside Medical Practices ndash demonstrated that patients who previously would have seen a GP were now seeing the right clinician at the right time for their specic needs.The new service, developed in partnership by Riverside, NHS  and ELHSCP, ensured that urgent care was dealt with on the same day and patients should have ldquono anxieties about being seen by the right professional at the right time.Through this new way of delivering patient care, it not only provided an increase in the number of patient appointments with practice GPs and other healthcare professionals, but also provided an increase in appointmentfor patients with complex needs.A recent survey conducted within the practice demonstrated that more than half of patients agreed that they did not always need to see a GP.Work is also under way by ELHSCP to implement a new telephone and IT system that will support call demand into the practice.The importance of patient involvement in getting services right is ldquovery much recognised by the practice, which is encouraging residents to get involved with the Patient Participation Group.Speaking after meeting with the Cabinet Secretary, Mr Beattie said: ldquoI would like to assure all of my constituents that patient care is of paramount importance and that all agencies involved in the new way services are being delivered within Musselburgh Primary Care Centre are focused on delivering the best care possible.ldquoRiverside Medical Practice is working with other organisations to ensure that improvements are made and I would encourage anyone with any issues regarding the practice to get in touch with them and become involved with the patient participation group.ldquoI am hopeful that the improvements being made by the organisations will be seen by patients and a vastly improved service will be delivered.ldquoI will continue to closely monitor the future performance of the practice and ask patients to keep me advised on whether the improvements are working.

title: seatbelt-embarrassment-spurs-on-musselburgh-couple-to-big-weight-loss
story: Derek Melon, , a customer services advisor, and his we Carole, , a mortgage advisor, of James Street, are both feeling ldquofantastic after their bumper weight loss, which was sparked by a holiday to Florida.Derek has dropped five stones from st lbs to st lbs, and Carole, who weighed in at st lbs, lost four-and-a-half stones to get to st lbs since they joined Weight Watchers in June last year.Their journey started after the couple, who have a teenage son, booked a holiday to Florida.Carole said: ldquoI was so excited but the plane journey going left me feeling humiliated and not happy as I had to request a seatbelt extension as I could not fasten the original seatbelt. Thankfully no one heard me asking for it but the embarrassment of having to ask was enough to spur me on.ldquoAt this point, on what should have been an exciting time, I was left feeling down, and it was then that I decided that it was time to lose weight.ldquoNever again did I want to be in that position of asking for an extension. The next time I was flying I wanted to be able to buckle up like any other person.ldquoWhen I ed, I decided to join Weight Watchers at Musselburgh Hope Church, and it was the best decision I have ever made.ldquoI have now lost more than four-and-a-half stones and feel fantastic. I find the Weight Watchers app amazing as its so easy to use and being able to track is really simple and motivating.ldquoI am a very fussy eater, and, on the plan, I can still have a treatI want. This makes le easy and no one really knows you are on a healthy eating plan as I can eat just like everyone .ldquoEverything about the Freestyle plan just suits me, and, even though I donrsquot eat meat or fish, I can still eat a lot of what I like.ldquoThe weekly workshops are very motivational and I love going. My wellness coach, Lisa Stewart, is so supportive, as well as all the other members.ldquoNow I can make the right choices, walk more and shop for clothes that I would never have been able to buy before. Clothes shopping has also become really enjoyable and less expensive as I no longer need to buy a size  but a rather smaller size .ldquoWalking has now become easier as I used to get breathless but this does not happen now. I have the motivation to keep going even when Irsquove put weight on as Irsquom not perfect.Derek was inspired to lose weight by Carole, saying: ldquoMy we joined Weight Watchers and her initial weight loss was inspiring. I knew I had to lose weight but I just never had the motivation to do anything about it.ldquoMy we was looking amazing and it was then that I knew it was time for me to get on the Weight Watchers wagon. Irsquom so glad I joined with Carole as I find it easy to follow.ldquoI can still eat my favourite snacks ndash crisps ndash which is something I was not prepared to give up. Thankfully I can enjoy these and still lose weight.ldquoDoing the Freestyle plan with Carole is really good although we do not always eat the same foods. The choice of foods that we can enjoy and eat means both us can enjoy what we want.ldquoThe support from the coach Lisa is fantastic and sometimes Irsquom the only male who stays for the weekly talk. This does not phase me as my weight loss is too important and everyone is really friendly. Even when my we canrsquot make it, I go on my own. Men should not be afraid of joining as Irsquove had a fantastic weight loss.ldquoMy food choices are now better and I pay more attention to what I eat. We both used to eat things like large bars of chocolate, deep-pan pizzas, lots of bread and cheese. There was no thought to what we were eating.ldquoWe now eat better with lots of fresh fruit and veg, and have more thought in what we are preparing and eating and are both enjoying our food much better.He added: ldquoA big tick to myself is that I can now buy jeans in Primark ndash something I was not able to do before. It sounds silly but being able to go and buy a  waist instead of a -inch waist just makes me smile. My top size used to be an XXXL but can now buy a size XL L, so itrsquos quite clear why I enjoy buying new clothes.

title: creche-closure-date-announced-for-enjoyleisure-centres
story: Enjoyleisure, which runs sports centres, swimming pools, sports pitches and two golf courses across the county, announced last month that creches would be closing following a drop in funding.Now, the charity has confirmed that the service will be withdrawn from noon on April .Bill Axon, general manager of enjoyleisure, said: ldquoI genuinely appreciate how disappointing such decisions can be for certain patrons, however, I can assure our customers and future customers, the Board of enjoy and myself are committed to ensuring the ongoing provision of sport, leisure and fun activities across East Lothian for many years to come.A petition, signed by nearly , people, was launched by a group of concerned parents under the banner lsquoChildren and Families of East Lothianrsquo following the announcement the creches would be closing.A group of parents contacted Iain Gray, MSP for East Lothian, about the issue and met with representatives from enjoyleisure in a bid to see the decision reversed.Mum-of-four Sarah Brunton was among those campaigning for the facilities to remain in place.She regularly uses the sports centres in Haddington, North Berwick and Dunbar and was disappointed to hear a date had now been set.And she warned the decision could lead to people cancelling their memberships.She said: ldquoBasically, the people I have spoken to, each and every one of us, will have to withdraw our membership."We have not got any other option.Over the past  years, since enjoyleisurersquos creation, the cregraveche service has been retained for the benefit of customers, despite operating at a shortfall.However, as user numbers continued to decline year upon year, the subsequent financial deficit increased the strain on the rest of the organisation.A spokeswoman for the group said ldquostrict adult to child ratios and current charging requirements reduce enjoyleisurersquos capacity of increasing income for this service, and at existing user levels, it is not possible to retain this provision at an affordable cost to customers.With ldquosubstantial increases in business operational costs and a drop in council funding, enjoyleisure took the decision to ldquore-evaluate its current financial and operational position in order to ensure the long-term sustainability and viability of the whole organisation.Mr Axon told the Courier: ldquoI also recognise the efforts of the lsquoChildren and Families of East Lothianrsquo, with whom I have met with personally, to outline our current position and provide further detail to the wider context within which has ultimately forced us into making these decisions.The general manager also described enjoyleisure staff as ldquoa credit to themselves.He added: ldquoWe would additionally like to take this opportunity to thank our customers and staff for their continued support and loyalty.ldquoAs a local charitable organisation, we cannot survive without your backing, and we are incredibly grateful for this.ldquoAs East Lothianrsquos sports and leisure charity, we work closely with East Lothian Council, local sports clubs and the wider community to maintain affordable access to safe and fit for purpose facilities to the best of our ability.ldquoThis, even though the financial environment within which we operate is currently exceptionally dficult, remains a principal objective.ldquoLikewise, to retain sport and leisure facilities in all our major towns, which allows for easy, local access for all our communities.

title: tranent-man-caught-in-paeodophile-hunters-sting
story: Andrew Grant, of Coalgate Avenue, sent written sexual communication to a lsquogirlrsquo called Lucy after making contact over social media.Grant, , also sent the lsquogirlrsquo a sexually explicit video and attempted to get the lsquogirlrsquo to view the images.But the lsquogirlrsquo turned out to be a decoy used by a paedophile hunter group which operates online.He pleaded guilty to the two offences at Edinburgh Sherf Court on March  and he was remanded in custody, pending sentencing.He ed to court from custody this week where he was handed a stringent community payback order as an alternative to a custodial sentence.Sherf Peter McCormack placed Grant on the sex offendersrsquo register for five years and ordered him to carry out  hours of unpaid work in the community.Grant was also given a two-year supervision order as well as a conduct requirement that contains ious elements regarding his use of the internet. Grant admitted sending written sexual communications and sending a sexually explicit video to a child at Thistle Street, Edinburgh, on February  and  this year.

title: gullane-gym-could-make-way-for-housing
story: Gullane Gym, on the villagersquos Hall Crescent, has been operating for more than  years after being transformed from an old garage workshop. However, the health facility could make way for four new flats under proposals from gym boss Allan Anderson.A design statement, included in plans submitted to East Lothian Council, says that Mr Anderson has been trying to make the business work for a number of years.The document reads: ldquoSince the commencement of the enterprise, Mr Anderson has continually provided outside finance to support the restricted trading of the business which, despite his best efforts and after persevering for  years, has determined that the financial viability of the venture is no longer affordable or justiable.ldquoThe gym is constrained by the restricted size of the property, which is indispensable for supporting sufficient amplied membership necessary to make the business justiable as a going concern, especially in the present climate of contemporary gyms providing -hour access for signicantly competitive deflated membership fees, not achievable in such a lesser populated area.ldquoMr Anderson has, over the past two years, attempted to sell Gullane Gym as a going concern but, despite several endeavours and dfering agents, the marketing of the property for use in any business capacity has been found to be impossible.ldquoIn the intervening two years to date, there has only been one instance of relevance, and that from a property development company, upon whose offer was subject to obtaining planning consent for the purpose that Mr Anderson is now wishing to acquire.ldquoThe situation is such that the business has become economically unviable.The plans,approved, would see the current building demolished.Four flats would then be built over two floors, with parking also included. Three of the four homes would include two bedrooms, with the remaining flat having a third bedroom.A summary for the application describes it as ldquorational that an alternative solution is found to prevent the site from stagnating once the gym closes.Ward councillor Jeremy Findlay, who lives in Gullane, could not comment fully on the proposals because he is a member of the councilrsquos planning committee, which could decide their fate.He said: ldquoI think I can probably go as far as to say I would be disappointedthe village lost yet another facility.

title: new-peer-flatmate-scheme-given-cash-boost
story: The project will put lsquocare-experiencedrsquo young people in flats with students to give peer support and improve options.The young people will share accommodation, giving each of them access to a low-cost home with mutual peer support.The council will be working alongside Hub for Success, which brings together Queen Margaret University, Newbattle Abbey College, Heriot Watt University, Napier University, Edinburgh College, The Open University and the University of Edinburgh. The funding, that has been provided by the Le Changes Trust as part of their Home and Belonging initiative. will be matched by the council.Initially, two furnished properties will be purchased by the council, where four care-experienced young people and two students will live. This number will increase to  properties over the course of the next three years, which will become homes to  care experienced young people and  peer flatmate students.Heather Coady, director of the Trustrsquos care experienced young people programme, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be supporting the Peer Flatmate project in East Lothian. Care-experienced young people have the same potential and aspirations as other young people, but generally they do not have access to the same supportive relationships as others when they begin to move into adulthood. Through our Home and Belonging initiative, we are investing in projects which offer creative and personalised responses to this challenge.The pound million lsquoHome and Belongingrsquo initiative, which granted the funds for the Peer Flatmate Scheme, was created to provide specic and creative support to young people who are ready to move on from care, and to give them a feeling of stability, warmth and security.A spokesperson from East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe believe this is the first project of this kind in the whole of Scotland and a great example of partnership working between council teams and external partners to make a real dference to the lives of some of our most vulnerable young people. The role of a Peer Flatmate will be to provide guidance and share their experience of shared living. This role is voluntary, with rent and costs such as WiFi covered through funding. A Housing Support provider will provide inidual and group support to each flat-share project, covering issues such as budgeting and shared living.

title: new-exhibition-delves-into-youth-culture-of-north-berwick
story: lsquoTeenage Kicks -rsquo has been created by North Berwick Youth Project and is the product of over two years of work for the group.Lauren Cowie, manager of the Youth Project, said: ldquoThe young people have been absolutely instrumental in getting this exhibition organised.ldquoThey made some films about what it was like being young in North Berwick today, and these secured funding from the National Lottery for the rest of the exhibition. They worked so hard and itrsquos really paid off.The exhibition includes toys and trinkets from years gone by as well as the chance to see the four films made by the members of the youth group.The films explore memories of growing up around North Berwick, teenage hangouts both past and present as well as the young people sharing their experiences of being involved in the project.Stefan Hughes, , is part of the Youth Project and was excited to take part.ldquoWe got to interview loads of people who told us how they used to live and what they used to do in the area, he said. ldquoIt was really interesting: though it seemed that so much of the cool things that they had back then arenrsquot there any more.He added: ldquoIt would be amazing to see North Berwick have more things for people of my age.Some of the exhibitions have already been displayed in a small pop-up event at the Hope Rooms which attracted over  people.Gordon Moodie, curator of the museum, is hoping that its popularity will continue throughout the summer.ldquoThe exhibition will run alongside the usual artefacts that we hold, so therersquos a lot to come and see, he said.ldquoItrsquos been amazing working with the Youth Project on this exhibition and the final product is very impressive.Sarah Dornan, the youth worker supporting the young people, said: ldquoWe really hope as many people will visit the exhibition, which will show what it was like to be young in North Berwick in the past. The young people wanted to make the exhibition as exciting and interesting as possible, so that it is really enjoyable for visitors, who can connect with the displays and share stories of their very own teenage kicks.The exhibition opens at the museum, on School Road, on Saturday.

title: former-courier-reporter-joel-sked-takes-to-television-screens-on-new-bbc-scotland-channel
story: Joel Sked is part of a three-man  which reflects on the beautul game across Scotland each Friday evening on A View From the Terrace.The former Courier reporter was delighted with the success of the show, which started off as a podcast a decade ago.He said: ldquoWe are just a group of football fans who love Scottish football ndash its peculiarities, the entertainment it provides, the characters and storylines it throws up.ldquoAll teams are treated equally. Wersquoll talk about Celtic, Rangers, Hearts and Hibs but wersquoll transition straight to Peterhead, Cowdenbeath or Stranraer and give them equal billing.ldquoWersquoll shine a light on clubs and players who donrsquot often find themselves in the limelight. And wersquoll do so in dferent, entertaining ways ndash whether that be the Boyata Index where we give players outlandish values, or through Beauty in the Lower Leagues, such as Arbroathshot by film director Wes Anderson.The programme, broadcast at pm on Fridays, sees Joel alongside Shaughan McGuigan and Craig Fowler, as well as host Craig Telfer.A View From the Terrace was commissioned for a -week run, with episode five being shown tomorrow.Joel, who spent  months working with the Courier from late , was unsure what would happen beyond the start of May.However, he was enjoying the programme, which is filmed each Wednesday at a studio in Uphall, West Lothian.Filming takes place over  hours, with each of those in front of the cameras carrying out meticulous research beforehand on a iety of topics.Former Knox Academy pupil Joel, of Haddingtonrsquos Knowesley Park, said there was an appetite for greater football coverage, particularly of the lower leagues, in Scotland.The -year-old said: ldquoThat has been my main takeaway from the first four weeks.ldquoPeople are really interested in football and might support Hearts, Hibs, Rangers or Celtic and only pay attention to those teams and have no real interest in the lower leagues ndash other than putting on a coupon.ldquoNow, they are being shown a dferent side to football at that level and have taken more of an interest in it.ldquoThey are more aware of the players and what teams do. I went to the game between Dumbarton and Arbroath to tick it off, as that was the only Scottish ground I had not been to.ldquoI went into a bar and someone spotted me and started talking to me.ldquoPeople at the ground came up to me to say how these teams had been ignored and they donrsquot get great coverage unless they are involved in a game with the Old Firm or a Premiership team.ldquoThey are getting a bit of publicity and we are giving teams publicity on a week by week basis.ldquoFans are grateful we are paying attention to them and shining a light on them.

title: driver-who-ignored-ban-is-ordered-to-stay-at-home-in-the-evening
story: Iain Vass, of Albert Place, was caught behind the wheel at Captainrsquos Drive in Edinburgh last December despite already receiving a road ban previously. Vass was also found to have no insurance following the police stop in the Capital on December .He had admitted the offence during an earlier appearance Edinburgh Sherf Court and he ed to court last Wednesday for sentencing.His solicitor Angela Craig said that her client had a ldquogood insight into his problems and that he was engaging with a rehabilitation service.Ms Craig said -year-old Vass had been visiting his partner and had decided to get behind the wheel after she had fallen ill while the couple were out for a drive.Ms Craig said it was on this journey that he was stopped by police and that he made ldquoa serious mistake.Sherf Peter McCormack said he took ldquoa dim view of people who drive while disqualied but stopped short of jailing the offender. Instead, the sherf handed out a restriction of liberty order for the next  days meaning Vass must stay indoors between the hours of pm and am.Vass was also banned from driving for a further  months and was admonished on the no insurance charge.

title: movie-star-michael-sheen-backs-hey-girls-new-campaign
story: #PadsDads has been launched by Hey Girls after its survey of , men found that one in three dads felt unprepared to have conversations about periods with their children.Meanwhile, a third said that they had never purchased sanitary products and half said they had never spoken to their daughters about periods.Now, Stenton-based Hey Girls has teamed up with actor, activist and father-of-one Michael Sheen to launch the campaign.#PadsDads is a movement to encourage men to talk to their daughters more about periods, but also an online guide, written by dads for dads, with all they need to know about the subject.Celia Hodson, who co-founded Hey Girls alongside her daughters Kate and Becky, was delighted to launch the campaign.She said: ldquoEducation is so important to break down the myths and taboo that still surround periods.ldquoEveryone in my family is totally used to chatting about periods now but I do understand talking to teenagers about puberty can be awkward.ldquoHowever, for dads of daughters with no female relatives around, it can be more than that ndash itrsquos often quite scary.ldquoWe wanted to create something empowering to give dads a helping hand.ldquoIt was a pleasure to work with Michael in doing so.Mr Sheen, who starred in Frost Nixon and The Damned United, was happy to back the campaign.He said: ldquoItrsquos awkward for dads to have this chat because, chances are, they didnrsquot learn about periods in school.ldquoBelieve me, we want to be supportive but therersquos almost no information out there aimed at dads.ldquoLetrsquos not leave dads out of the conversation!Hey Girls has enjoyed a meteoric rise since it was unveiled last year.The company was launched selling menstrual products online using a lsquoBuy One Give Onersquo model: for every box purchased, a box is given away to a girl or woman in need in the UK.In its first  months, the organisation was recognised as one of Scotlandrsquos start-up innovators.Aileen Campbell MSP, cabinet secretary for communities and local government, congratulated Hey Girls for taking action.She said: ldquoWe are leading the way in Scotland to provide access to free sanitary products and talk more openly about menstruation.ldquoI am proud to see Hey Girls taking action to reduce the stigma around periods as a female-only conversation.ldquoIt is important to engage dads and other male role models by encouraging them to talk about this important subject.

title: ross-high-school-pupil-dances-alongside-brendan-cole
story: Bobby Duncan, from Tranent, performed at the Playhouse Theatre, Edinburgh in the hit dance show lsquoShowmanrsquo where he danced to hits from musicals such as the Greatest Showman and La La Land.The -year-old is a member of the MGA Academy Fierce Theatre School in Edinburgh, and has his eyes firmly set on stage.ldquoWhatever happens I know I want to be performing professionally, he said, though he admitted to feeling a little nervous before his big performance.He added: ldquoI always get nervous, but at the Playhouse I was especially affected by its size.ldquoI think itrsquos a good thing to be nervous though ndash it just shows you care. It was a bit surreal.ldquoWe had to walk out and turn on to the stage and at that moment I was just so taken aback. I watch shows at the Playhouse myself once or twice a year and so to be dancing on the same stage was incredible.This isnrsquot Bobbyrsquos first time in the spotlight, having performed in The Wizard of Oz at the Kingrsquos Theatre in Edinburgh, but dancing on stage with Brendan Cole was still extra special, especially for his family.ldquoI had my mum, nan and gran there watching me who are all absolute super fans of Strictly Come Dancing. They were so excited to see me and, of course, Brendan perform.Preparation for the show was intense, with Bobby and the rest of the dancers only having four weeks to learn all the choreography and the songs, and then they had only one technical rehearsal before performing in front of a live audience.Louise Ferrier, principal of The MGA Academyrsquos school of part-time studies, said: ldquoThis was an incredible opportunity for our students. They are all in awe of Brendan Cole as they recognised him from Strictly. They were all very excited and were thrilled to have the chance to perform with renowned professionals in the largest theatre in the UK. We love offering our junior school studentsrsquo regular opportunities like this, as they respond so well, are an absolute credit to themselves and enjoy it so much. Experiences such as this one allows them to learn from the best in the business.

title: teenager-involved-in-skiing-accident-set-to-return-to-school
story: Nicholas Guest, of Lawson Way, Tranent, was skiing with friends over the Christmas holidays at a resort in the Swiss Alps when he went over a jump and hit his head.He was in a coma in a hospital in Sion while his family flew over to him.A crowdfunding campaign was set up to help get him home and, when he woke up, he ed to Scotland at the end of January.Now, after being discharged from the Astley Ainslie Hospital in Edinburgh, the -year-old is planning toto school this week.ldquoHersquoll go back to school for a few hours to begin with and see what challenges he faces and how his concentration levels are, said mum Marian.ldquoThe school will allow him to leave class a little early so hersquos not in the corridor at the same time as everyone , as he still canrsquot risk banging his head.Nicholas, who plays rugby for Preston Lodge RFCrsquos under-s, will still have to attend physiotherapy once a week to help his movement and co-ordination.ldquoHe looks forward to it now, Marian added.ldquoItrsquos a chance for him to perfect his walking skills. He presented the ball at the rugby club for their match on Saturday and he was so happy. It was quite emotional seeing him back in the place that he loves so much.ldquoWersquoll find out in a few weeks when we get the result of the scan whether hersquoll be able to play rugby again. Wersquore staying positive.Nicholas is in fth year at Preston Lodge and had been due to take exams later this year.ldquoHis exams will be moved back a year as obviously he has been unable to revise andhe took them this year it wouldnrsquot be a fair reflection on his abilities, she added.The rugby club will be hosting a rugby game in honour of brain injury charity Headway East Lothian at the end of May.

title: tims-tales-im-a-happy-caveman
story: IN MANY ways, old age is a relative concept, for as we get older we tend to push the goalpost of old age further up the scale. Irsquom not yet really old, as Irsquom still in my s, but relative to how young I used to be, Irsquom old by any measure I used in my days of youth.And there seem few benefits in getting older.As one friend recently told me, ldquoIf, at our age, you donrsquot have a pain or ache somewhere, then yoursquore probably deid.But I think there is a tipping point in all this getting old process, whereby you stop resisting the idea, and not only accept it, but embrace it. I think I have reached that point.My age has become a kind of achievement given my lestyle, and I have a deep recognition that every day is something to savour, even when, as is the case as I now write, the weather outside is cold, wet and just miserable.And storytelling is a profession in which getting older is not seen as a disadvantage, because oldness in a storyteller can add a bit more authenticity.But my storytelling profession also highlights my disconnection to what people call progress. Increasingly in my work with children, I am being made aware of the gap between what is going on in technological developments and my knowledge of it.Often in accounts of daily le, things are mentioned by children and I have absolutely no idea what they are. Usually they are new computer games or computer technology.These games are so much part of so many childrenrsquos lives that when I ask what they are they find it incredible that I have no knowledge of them.One of them responded cheekily, but in an affectionate manner, ldquoTim do you live in a cave In a sense I suppose I do. I am lucky to have a young family as well as a grown up one, and that keeps me young at heart. But so far I have managed to resist the computer game thing, although I know how addictive it can be because I recently I tried a game once in a friendrsquos house.I felt a bit like Frodo Baggins when he put on the ring. Something took over my soul and for a moment I was being taken over by an uncontrollable desire. I didnrsquot actually say the words ldquomy precious screen when I was forced to leave, but that is how I felt.In one way, my lack of experience with this kind of technology makes me feel old and disconnected from the modern world but, on the other hand, it makes me feel relieved and even privileged that I grew up in an age when such toxic distractions from living le were simply not available.I remember climbing trees, mucking about at the beach, playing in the garden till it got dark, making dens, cycling on an old bike that had been thrown away, going round for pals basically being almost constantly outside and usually dirty when I finally came home. No wonder children assume there was no electricity in the days of my youth, because when I describe it, there is an absence of devices.I did, of course, watch TV, but programmes were limited, no morning TV for example, and childrenrsquos TV was over by teatime. The outdoors was ldquomy precious and being bored was a motivation to make a game with pals not switch on a screen.Only now, looking back, do I realise just how much a privilege it was to have a childhood free of this screen addiction. It simply wasnrsquot an option so there was no sense of loss or missing out.But now with a young family I wonder how much longer I can hold out.After a trip to North Berwick the other day I was asked by my youngest daughter, ldquoWhat are those things on the seat  as she peered into a car parked next to ours at a supermarket car park.They were the frame holdersfor ipads, so the children can watch films or play games while in the car. I realised my daughter had no idea that such a thing was possible!I explained how it was much better to sing songs, tell stories, play word games and look out the window and play ldquoI spy. She nodded her head, but Irsquom not sure she was convinced.I know Irsquom coming across as an old self righteous dinosaur. I do realise, of course, that the ldquogood old days were not all good.I also understand that kids, indeed le itself, can be hard work, and all this new technology can help make our lives easier. It can help us keep us entertained and connected in a dferent way, and make information easier to get.But even still, when children look at me in horror when I explain the absence of technology in my childhood and they ask me, ldquobut what did you do, I feel a sense of sadness that we have allowed the giants of IT multinationals to steal the imaginations, and the precious childhood time, of our children and future generations.In that sense I think storytellers are needed perhaps more than ever. I remain happy living in my ldquocave. And when it is finally time for my own lights to go out, I hope I will have left a trail of stories and experiences.In the end, surely, that legacy is worth more than a thousand computer games played.

title: ambitious-plans-revealed-for-the-bell
story: Kurt Edwards and Laura McSweeney will step behind the bar at The Bell next month, with plans for a fresh outlook and a name change.Mr Edwards and Miss McSweeney are behind Eats on the Green, which handles catering at Haddington Golf Club, with Graeme Flick set to become head chef at the pub, which was previously The Railway Hotel.Thirty-eight-year-old Mr Edwards said: ldquoWe have got children and we found there was a need for a family pub in East Lothian.ldquoWe had been going to The Pine Marten in Dunbar but there was nowhere for us take the children.ldquoI spoke to Greene Kingand we came up with the idea to put in a play area upstairs and they were all for it.The trio will officially be handed the keys on April  and will put in a new till system and run the business until the end of the month.Then, the final bell will toll for The Bell, with a new name of The Green when the business reopens.Mr Edwards said there would be a similar outlook at the Court Street business as to their business at the golf club, with an emphasis on ldquoworking with local suppliers, everything made in house and tasty food.He added: ldquoWe are going to lose the big screen television upstairs.ldquoIt was just not working and we are going to get a couple of screens downstairs.ldquoUpstairs will be more of a family environment and we are going to change the bar and add a coffee machine.ldquoThere will be cakes and sweet stuff, plus alcohol.ldquoDownstairs will be more of a pub and we will have a food offering sothere is a game on you can get a pint and a meal during the game.A spokeswoman for Greene King wished the new parties well.She said: ldquoWersquore thrilled that Kurt and Laura have agreed to take on The Bell and we wish them all the best with their new venture.ldquoWe made a signicant investment in this pub in recent years and wersquove spent time recruiting the right partners who we believe can take the pub forward and continue to ensure its success at the heart of Haddington.Haddington and Lammermuir ward member Councillor Tom Trotter also wished those involved the best of luck.He said: ldquoYou go further down the street and see what has happened to some of the pubs.ldquoHopefully, they get a turn and make a success of it.Meanwhile, The Victoria Inn, which is also owned by Greene King, remains on the market after a potential buyer fell through.

title: 20km-diversion-may-drive-you-crazy
story: A km stretch of the B at Mayshiel, south east of Gford,will be shut for three days from Monday to allowcarriageway resurfacing to take place.The ersion route takes drivers on a km tour through East Lothian villages, includingGarvald and Gford, beforerejoining the road west of Mayshiel.The B passing the entrance to Mayshiel Farm. Image by James Denham and licensed for reuse under a Creative Commons LicenceThe section of road will close between .am and .pm each day of the work.East Lothian Council said it had timed the work to be carried out during the school holidays as some school buses used the route.But they said while the ersion route was km-long, people would be able to find alternative ways to bypass the closure.A spokesperson said: ldquoThe resurfacing work will require the road to be closed as this road is only five metres wide which means that the road surfacing equipment and workers cannot safely carry out the required work without temporary closure.ldquoAs some school buses use this route, the work is being carried out during the school Easter break and a ersion route is in place.ldquoTheof the full ersion route is km but it is unlikely that anyone would follow this full route as other alternatives are also available which would only add -km to the usual access between Gfordto Duns.

title: trios-delight-at-being-named-members-of-scottish-youth-parliament
story: Adnan Ros and Nathaniel de Havilland will represent East Lothian, with Erin Campbell representing Midlothian North and Musselburgh. The elections finished last Friday afternoon and Knox Academy pupil Adnan was thrilled to become a MSYP.The -year-old said: ldquoMy issues range is a lot but my main focus is a change to how National  is viewed, as in viewed as an alternative path rather than something thatrsquos used to scare kids into revising. I also would love to do more with all minority communities and develop safe spaces and friendships within schools and youth centres!Meanwhile, -year-old Nathaniel, of North Berwick High School, said: ldquoI am exceptionally excited to be able to represent the young people of East Lothian in the SYP. I look forward to setting in motion my agenda to improve on Scotlandrsquos great track record of minimising its carbon footprint.ldquoI wish also to encourage more council spending for those who are disadvantaged to further improve the quality of education.ldquoI am very excited to begin my work within the constituency and I fervently hope to make it a better place for all.Erin, who attends Musselburgh Grammar School, was delighted to secure the seat for the next two years.The -year-old said: ldquoI am over the moon to have been elected to represent my constituency of Midlothian North and Musselburgh.ldquoI love my constituency and the people I represent and so I want to ensure that the young people here have the best opportunities in the future, as I truly believe that our voices are extremely valuable and should be listened to, respected and acted upon.

title: new-tie-in-at-knox-academy-for-the-pupils
story: Pupils were asked for their thoughts on the idea of new ties, one of which would mark achievements with the second tie to represent each of the schoolrsquos houses ndash Garleton, Lammerlaw and Traprain.Sue Cook, headteacher, said: ldquoOur school values are ambition, respect and community.ldquoWe have been focusing on all these values throughout the year but a recent pupil survey highlighted that pupils wanted us to be better at us recognising their achievements both in and out of school.ldquoAfter consulting with a group of pupils, parents and staff, the idea of an achievement tie was agreed.ldquoThis tie can be awarded for a iety of reasons such as representing school teams over the season, supporting or leading others in the school or wider community, and working diligently in all school subjects throughout the year.The new ties, which will replace the existing navy blue version featuring the school logo, will form part of the school unorm from the   session.Miss Cook, who became headteacher at the school last year, encouraged parents and carers to get in touch with the school about the achievements of youngsters.She added: ldquoWe have such an array of talent here it would be a shame not to recognise and reward this.ldquoAchievement ties are paid for by the school.Each of the  pupils at the school had the chance to vote for two options on the house tie.Parents and carers were also given the chance to give their views on the proposals.The house ties will feature a diagonal band, with the colour ndash green, yellow or red ndash representing the pupilrsquos house ndash Garleton, Lammerlaw and Traprain.Meanwhile, youngsters and parents and carers were also given a choice regarding the achievement ties.The most popular option will result in dferent ties for senior pupils and BGEpupils.Senior pupils will have a tie with two gold diagonal stripes and a stripe representing their house, with the younger pupils only having a single gold band and a stripe representing their house.

title: volunteers-from-dunbars-rnli-honoured
story: Volunteers past and present, in roles ranging from leboat fundraisers and committee members to shop workers and crew, were recognised for their ldquooutstanding service.On a special night that brought Dunbarrsquos leboat family together, presentations were made to  volunteers who have contributed to the running and support of the townrsquos leboats over many years on behalf of Dunbar leboat management group, the leboat fundraising committee and the crew.Mark Lees, chairman of the leboat management group, said the event, which was held at the townrsquos Royal British Legion, was about expressing appreciation to the service that volunteers from all walks of le had made to the Dunbar community.He added: ldquoThe crew might be the ones out there keeping people safe but they would not be able to do what they do without the support of everyone .ldquoWe all share a long history with the leboat station in Dunbar.ldquoWhat we have here is so very special.ldquoThatrsquos what makes the town of Dunbar such an amazing place.Ken Headley, who manages the townrsquos two leboat shops, said that the work of volunteers had helped make Dunbarrsquos High Street store number one in Scotland and among the top  performing shops in the UK.Presenting awards on behalf of the fundraising committee, Veronica Davies, chairwoman, said her volunteers continued to break records, with her team helping to raise more than pound, last year, including a best-ever leboat fete, which raised pound,, and Strictly for the Leboats ndash a weekend of dancing fun ndash which raised pound,.She added: ldquoThank you to everyone on the fundraising committee for all your hard work. Itrsquos been absolutely amazing.Gary Fairbairn, coxswain, paid tribute to former crew members who were receiving vellums for outstanding service.He said: ldquoBeing on the crew means we share some good times and some genuinely funny moments, as well as the bad times, which can sometimes be pretty horric.ldquoIt means you have to handle a lot.ldquoThatrsquos why itrsquos good to be able to present awards to people for their service on the crew.Receiving awards for voluntary service to the shop were: Pam Denholm , Margaret Headley , Sue Barnott , Pat Wilson and Shona McManus , Agnes Wilson and Margaret Brown .Awards also went to seven people who were unable to attend: Maureen Watt , Pat Bower , Jean Rae , Sally Drysdale , Linda Baines and Liz Brown , and Wendy Badger .Receiving awards for voluntary service to the fundraising committee were: Moira Porter , Sheon Cairns , Fiona Fleming , Ken Headley , Martha Windram , Pat Wilsonand Katy Pollock . An award also went to Elizabeth Hutton , who was unable to attend.Receiving vellums for voluntary service to the crew were: Douglas Gillan , Andrew Middlemiss , Mike Shawand Dayna Dryer .As Dayna was unable to attend, her award was collected by her grandmother Martha Windram.Special awards from the RNLI for outstanding service to the fundraising committee also went to Martha Windram and Fiona Fleming.

title: call-made-for-the-hayweights-clock-to-return-to-its-home
story: Councillor Stuart Currie is asking the community to support his proposal to lsquoBring the Hayweights Clock Back Home!rsquo, stressing that he was keen to initiate ldquoa healthy debate on the future site of the clock which could be used as a tourist information point.The clock was moved from its North High Street location in the late s and now occupied a grass area in Mall Avenue, opposite the Tesco superstore.Mr Currie said: ldquoIn recent months many local folk have said to me that it is a real shame that the Hayweights Clock is currently nowhere near its original site next to the Brunton Hall in Fisherrow.ldquoI want to start the debate on whether there are strong feelings either way.He explained: ldquoMy own view is thatit is possible to have such a historic clock back where it was originally, then that must be an option to be considered.ldquoI would love to see the clock at the heart of tourist information about our amazing town.ldquoI also think it would be great to have young people from our construction academy involved in the workit was to go ahead to create a lasting legacy.He added: ldquoIf looking at this is thought worthwhile then I would very much want to work with local residents and organisations to identy potential funding sources.ldquoWhen I look at old photographs from decades ago and see the clock where it was at the Hayweights then surely it is worth having a debate about making sure our local history is in the right place wherever that is possible. I look forward to the discussion and hearing local views.The original Hayweights building, which was constructed in the s, did not have a clock on it.The clock was presented to the town in  by A.M. Black Esq, Writer to the Signet, as a token of affection and was was mounted in an ogee roof which gave the building a new feature.The purpose of the building was to house a mechanism used to weigh vehicles ndash originally horses and carts with hay ndash standing on a weighing plate adjacent to and outside the building.One of the weighmen was Peter Livingstone, who had one leg, and manned the weighbridge office for  years from am till pm daily, collecting the revenue for the town from the vehicles laden with sand and gravel, taken from the foreshore under licence, and other items.When the adjacent Brunton Hall was built, the clock and tower were removed for storage to a council yard.After a period of years the clock was installed in the clock tower of Stuartrsquos Net Mill ndash replacing its similar, original clock that had failed.Financed by Tesco, the wooden ogee tower, protected by lead with an new digital clock installed, was erected on pillars in the car parking area at The Mall. The lead was stolen at some later date and replaced with a new covering.The petition is available to view at https:www.change.org p east-lothian-council-bring-the-hayweights-clock-back-home

title: church-bids-for-extension-to-serve-the-community
story: Pastor Andrew Agnew said ground behind the existing church would offer a sizeable new hall to seat  people and accommodate a small stage. A further room would also cater for the church creche as well as meetings of the Sunday School and Bible class.They hope to hold weddings and funerals as well as opening up use of the extension to community groups, such as fitness and dance classes.With hundreds of new homes being built around Wallyford, Mr Agnew stressed that there was a need to meet the demands of a growing community.ldquoWe have to make sure we are here for our community and we feel this would be a real bonus to the community ndash our space just now is desperately limited, he said.Mr Agnew said he has to direct people who want to use the church facility to nearby St Clementrsquos Church Hall.Wallyford Livingroom Church, which builds on the work of many years of the old Wallyford Mission, occupies East Cottage, the former home of the coal board manager which appears on a  ordinance survey map.Mr Agnew, from Dungannon, Northern Ireland, worked in Mexico with street children before being appointed pastor at the Wallyford Living Church. He and his we Carol have three children.

title: community-welcomes-new-church-minister
story: A service of induction for the Rev Dr Leslie Milton, conducted by the Rev Andrew Don, Moderator of Lothian Presbytery, was held at the High Street kirk.A tea, hosted by the congregation of St Andrewrsquos High, took place afterwards at Inveresk Church Hall.The Rev Glover introduced Dr Milton to the congregation and the Rev Janice Andrews, of Musselburgh Congregational Church, welcomed him to the town on behalf of the local clergy. Alastair Knowles, immediate past president of the Old Musselburgh Club and chairman of the  Riding of the Marches, speaking on behalf of the local community, wished Dr Milton and his we Libby happiness for their new le in Musselburgh.Dr Milton, who grew up in Airdrie, was previously minister at Cambuslang Parish Church.Before that he worked as a minister of the Church of Scotland in a number of dferent countries, including times in South Africa and in Mozambique, where he taught students who were training to be ministers. He also worked for a Church of England training college near Oxford for eight years.Mrs Milton is a palliative care nurse, working at the Marie Curie Hospice in Fairmilehead. Dr Milton succeeds the kirkrsquos former minister Reverend Yvonne Atkins who retired.

title: community-keen-to-take-over-prestonpans-town-hall
story: The historic building at the centre of Prestonpans was identied by East Lothian Council as one of six viable properties suitable for a Community Asset Transfer , offering local organisations the chance to either buy or lease them.The community council put in a note of interest following its meeting last month.A sub committee of the group has also been set up to help progress the project: it features community councillors DJ Johnston-Smith, Calum Miller and Professor Roger Bromley.Their job will be to explore the possibility of creating a development trust which could facilitate the community asset transfer.Mr Johnston-Smith said: ldquoWe have been discussing for a number of years the enormous potential that our under-utilised historic town hall presents as a possible catalyst for the positive transformation of our High Street and historic town centre.ldquoSo, when the opportunity of a CAT of the site was presented to us by the council, we decided to set up a sub-committee to explore the details of the council proposal. As part of our remit we shall also be investigating similar heritage building transfers to communities where to better understand what others have done when assuming community stewardship of historic buildings in their towns.Mr Miller said the first task would be to establish the ldquobest model for the trust and engage with East Lothian Council.He added: ldquoThe ambition for the trust is much broader in scope than the management and development of one building: we will be reviewing unused or underdeveloped assets throughout Prestonpans and seeking ideas for bringing them back to le.ldquoWe have a first-class interim board in place to kickstart the project but we are looking for additional trust members to get involved. Anyone interested in helping out can reach us via the community council Facebook page.The running costs of the town hall are about pound, pr annum, which would have to be absorbed by any group which successfully takes control of the building.The hall was built in , designed by local architect Paul Whitecross, and has been used as a community building ever since.Now it is used for a day-time lunch club, childrenrsquos groups and activities and is also available for renting for party space.Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell, of East Lothian Council, said: ldquoThis is a great opportunity for the Prestonpans community and I am pleased that the community council is taking this first step. I want to encourage local people to get involved with their ideas for what use the community could make of this resource.ldquoThere have been some really positive discussions at the community council about the potential to improve the facility and to breathe new le into High Street.ldquoWith all that energy and enthusiasm, and with the support of the community, I think the transfer of the town hall building could bring real benefit to Prestonpans.Any group in the community can put a note of interest in for the CAT identied properties, and East Lothian Council has confirmed that ldquosome expression of interest has been received and a very thorough evaluation of these will take place in due course.The other properties the council noted for CAT were East Linton Council Chamber, Gullane Recreation Hall, Macmerry Village Hall, Stoneyhill Community Centre in Musselburgh and Trevelyan Hall in Pencaitland.

title: creating-a-dig-for-victory-garden-at-unloved-space
story: Jan Wallace, from Musselburgh, and Ros Parkyn and Caroline Tait, from Prestonpans, who set up the living history group Catching the Past, saw an opportunity to bring the overgrown site near the Fisherrow Centre in South Street to le as a lsquoGarden for Storiesrsquo.With help from Musselburgh Area Partnership and East Lothian Council, which cleared the garden and laid a path to ensure better access, the public will be invited to storytelling events around a tree with seating.Visitors will also get chance to take a step back in time to see a Dig for Victory Garden, inspired by the gardens which were part of daily le during the First and Second World Wars. This will be a focal point of the new outdoor facility.An Anderson bomb shelter will also installed in the ground and vegetables and herbs planted.The Fisherrow Trust is also hoping to create its own space in part of the garden which will be used by groups from the nearby Fisherrow Centre which was formerly a school.Jan explained that there was an even earlier school on the site. And that when the initial garden work was being carried out, a Victorian earthenware inkwell was unearthed which the group will use at their living history events.She added: ldquoPeople can use the garden where they can enjoy lunch when wersquore not around.Caroline explained the concept of the Dig for Victory Garden, saying: ldquoThere were food embargoes during the Second World War and everybody was made to use every bit of ground ndash parks were dug up. They were encouraged to dig their gardens and plant their own vegetables to survive. Food that was normally coming in from abroad wasnrsquot because of the embargoes on the ships. People would grow runner beans, potatoes and carrots. It was like your own mini-allotment in your gardenyou had the space.She said the group would create a similar garden at the Musselburgh site which it would maintain.ldquoThey often planted certain flowers in between as well so we will do likewise but most of the garden was for food production, added Caroline.Ros said they planned to attract wildle by planting a wildflower garden.She added: ldquoWe would also like to do a mobile garden so we could visit care homes and get the memories of residents.The group has received pound, for the garden project from environmental group the Mushroom Trust.Ros said they would be seeking other funding sources for the garden which could be open in August September.The group is passionate about social history and living history experiences. Through crafts, storytelling, drama and music, it seeks to bring people of all ages together to discover the past. Events are aimed at encouraging dferent generations to share their experiences and interests. The group uses antiques, vintage memorabilia and costumes to bring events to le.

title: primary-school-headteacher-announces-shes-leaving-this-summer
story: Jill Wareham emailed parents and carers at the North Berwick School this morning to tell them of her pending departure.She said: "I am writing to inform you of my plans to retire from my post as headteacher of Law Primary at the end of the current academic session in June."I have informed Fiona Robertson, head of education [at East Lothian Council], and she will take steps to recruit my successor in due course."And she added: "It has been a privilege to lead the team at Law for the last seven years. It would be dficult to find a more committed, enthusiastic and caring staff team to be teaching and looking after your children."Mrs Wareham then wished all parents and carers "an enjoyable Easter holiday".

title: deal-reached-to-sell-part-of-former-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: However, the size of the site which has been set aside is understood to be less than a third of the land originally proposed by the company.The local authority has announced that it has signed an options agreement with Inch Cape for a ldquosmall part of the former power station site, which is understood to be about seven acres of the -acre site.It has also agreed to the land used being to the far west of the site originally planned and set back from the coastline.Inch Cape won planning permission to build the substation, which will bring energy onshore from an offshore wind farm, earlier this year after Scottish Ministers controversially called in the planning application and granted approval.The original plans from Inch Cape cover a wider -acre site on the land on an area which was part of the footprint of the former power station itself.Concerns raised about the impact it would have on developing the rest of the site, which was purchased by East Lothian Council from ScottishPower last March, had been raised, as well as the visual impact on the coast.Inch Cape has consistently pledged to reduce the size of the substation, which will be remotely operated, to as small a footprint as possible.The reduced site was welcomed by East Lothian MSP Iain Gray, who had opposed the planning decision being take out of local authority hands.He said: ldquoHowever, with permission for the substation granted by ministers, this is a good outcome, with the size of the construction signicantly reduced and the actual site moved away from the waterfront.ldquoEast Lothian Council has minimised the area they had to sell, and hopefully that means progress can now be made on finding the right opportunity to create jobs and boost the local economy.Bryan Hickman, chairman of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, which opposed the site during the Scottish Government Reporterrsquos enquiry, said: ldquoInch Cape have consistently consulted with us on all matters relating to this application. We look forward to seeing a final plan showing the overall design.However, Brian Weddell, chairman of neighbouring Prestonpans Community Council, which also opposed the substation, raised concerns about the decision to sell the land and its long-term future.Prestonpans Community Council is lobbying for a cruise terminal to be based at the site.Mr Weddell said: ldquoIt remains the view of the Prestonpans community that the transformer is heading for the wrong location.ldquoHowever, we recognise that construction is going ahead regardless and we need to plan for the future.ldquoWe welcome the smaller footprint and believe the cruise ship terminal could easily be accommodated on the adjacent site.ldquoWe are concerned about the sale of this valuable site and the loss of public ownership what happens in  years when the wind farm is decommissioned Monica Patterson, depute chief executive of East Lothian Council, said: ldquoWe are pleased to have reached an agreement which will enable a substantially smaller area of the western site to be purchased from the council.ldquoThis means signicant land will remain available for opportunities to boost the local economy and create employment opportunities.Guy Madgwick, CEO of Red Rock Power, which owns Inch Cape, told the Courier: ldquoThis is a key milestone for the Inch Cape project and a signicant step forward in our plans to deliver a project with such national economic importance as well as contributing signicantly to Scotlandrsquos renewable energy targets.The purchase of the site will follow the progression of the Inch Cape Offshore Wind Farm project as a whole.Further details of the option agreement are commercially confidential at this stage.

title: football-fan-enjoys-managing-hibs-for-the-day
story: But one lucky Hibs fan was given the chance to do just that by taking the Easter Road club for a day, thanks to the Walk With Scott Foundation.Derek Ross, from London, was given the chance to step into the managerial hot seat at East Mains, on the outskirts of Ormiston and Hibsrsquo training ground, thanks to the Tranent-based charity.Councillor Colin McGinn, who is a board member with the charity, was delighted to take part in the day, which saw Mr Ross shadowing Hibees boss Paul Heckingbottom.The councillor said: ldquoWe got the guided tour and got to meet the manager and the players and all the backroom staff.ldquoWe had lunch with the first team squad but the key thing was just how accommodating and how welcoming everybody at the club was.ldquoWe did not feel we were a hindrance to the extent we were allowed into the press conference.ldquoPaul Heckingbottom invited Derek up to sit beside him during the press conference and he was introduced as the manager for the day.The prize of managing Hibs for a day was auctioned off by the charity, which aims to promote health and wellbeing in the area.Derekrsquos bid of pound, secured him the top prize and the chance to become a manager.Mr McGinn described the football fan as ldquoclearly a Hibs fanatic, with the group visiting the training ground ahead of the Capital sidersquos - draw with Kilmarnock and derby-day win over arch-rivals Hearts.The charity was founded by Tranent resident Scott Glynn, who was unable to attend the training session, Mr McGinn going instead.Mr McGinn, who is also a Hibernian fan, told the Courier he felt like ldquoa kid in the sweetie shop.He added: ldquoScott knows Neil Lennon [ex-Hibs boss and now Celtic manager] through the after-dinners speaking circuit that they do.ldquoWe were a bit concerned as a board with the change of manager at Hibs and whether this would happen. The new manager has to get on with his own stuff but George Craig, head of football operations at Hibs, was fantastic.ldquoWhen Scott got in touch, Hibs said they would honour it.ldquoThey increased the offer and it was just to be one person originally but Derek got to bring a couple of family members along.ldquoHibs increased the offer and it was a wonderful day.

title: redeveloped-former-co-op-building-in-tranent-about-to-open
story: The building on Winton Place has been converted into a Post Office, convenience store and coffee shop by well-known local couple George and Susan Thomson.The Thomsons worked closely with Historic Environment Scotland during the redevelopment.The opening ndash with the coffee shop opening at am tomorrow ndash marks the end of phase one for the Thomsons.
