title: first-outdoor-classroom-planned-for-east-lothian-school
story: Aberlady Primary School is set to be the first school in the county to have its own bespoke outdoors classroom built in its grounds.Overlooking the woods next to the village school, the room will be used by its nursery and will be built with timber and corrugated steelDescribed as off-grid, it will not have an electricity supply but will instead use solar  to charge a battery which will be used to power lighting in winter months.Composting toilet facilities will also be included in the plans, although they will be in a separate timber building outside the classroom.The modest classroomwill, according to plans, ldquosit quietly and comfortably within the existing grounds, providing a valuable and forward-thinking resource for the school and community of Aberlady.Applying for planning permission for the outdoors classroom, East Lothian Councilrsquos education department said that the school needed to expand its nursery provision to meet the increased hours which were being introduced.The Scottish Government wants all nursery-eligible children to be given , hours of free nursery care from August next year.A spokesperson for the local authority said that outdoor learning and classroomswere recognisedinternationally as a key development that could improve health and learning for youngsters.They said: ldquoThe proposal is for a self-contained early-years unit that is lsquooff-gridrsquo beside the schoolrsquos woodland area, which is a popular space already used by children and staff for play and outdoor learning.ldquoOnce completed,Aberladyrsquos design could act as a catalyst to developing further educational facilities across the county, offering children more opportunities to learn, play and connect with the outdoors.ldquoIngeneral terms, they [outdoor classrooms] allow children and staff the opportunity to explore their natural environment whilst also providing shelter from particularly inclement weather.ldquoChildren can gather together for snacks and group learning experiences throughout the nursery day.ldquoWe have been working with the school community and partners to develop a design that will best suit their needs.

title: north-berwick-named-in-top-10-places-to-live-in-scotland
story: Dundee came top as the best place to live in Scotland, according to the Sunday Times Best Places to Live.The study assesses a wide range of factors, from employment, schools and broadband speed to culture, community spirit and local shops.North Berwick and Dundee are the only two places in the top  which also made last years list.The other eight locations to make the list are: Leith, Edinburgh Stockbridge, Edinburgh Finnieston, Glasgow Killearn, Stirling Kilmacolm, Renfrewshire Mull Port Appin, Argyll and Bute and St Boswells, Scottish Borders.

title: hospice-residents-enjoy-virtual-reality-thanks-to-east-linton-company
story: Thanks to East Linton-based Viarama, the interactive initiative, which can virtually transport patients to locations on the other side of the world, will look at the impact of virtual realityon their health and wellbeing.An initial group of six residents at St Columbarsquos Hospice in Edinburgh benefited from the transformative effects of VR when they were offered the chance to revisit some of their favourite places or explore a part of the world they had never seen.Using the latest high-tech VR headsets, one inidual was transported to Jerusalem, a place he had always dreamed of visiting.In another session, a -year-old woman was thrilled to revisit her childhood home in Darjeeling and indulge in a trip up the Amazon river for the first time.The experience triggered happy memories with the opportunity to reminisce about old times, as well as encounter new places.The patients also took the chance to immerse themselves in an under-sea adventure.Through the use of VR, the patients could explore a sunken wreck with fish circling overhead while an enormous whale passed by.The initial virtual reality taster was run by Billy Agnew, founder of Viarama ndash said to be the worldrsquos first virtual reality social enterprise, which uses the power of VR as a force for good within communities across Scotland.He is now working along with Queen Margaret University at Musselburgh and St Columbarsquos on a research project involving  hospice patients.The project will look at the potential benefit of VR with a focus on patientsrsquo mood, pain and stress levels, as well as overall wellbeing.Mr Agnew said: ldquoWe look forward to giving many more hospice patients in Scotland the opportunity to enjoy the best VR experiences available, whilst exploring and measuring the many ways in which we believe VR helps people receiving palliative care.Dr Erna Haraldsdottir, senior lecturer in nursing at Queen Margaret University and director of education and research at St Columbarsquos Hospice, said: ldquoThanks to a grant from the Margaret Murphy Charitable Trust and generosity from Viarama, St Columbarsquos Hospice and QMU are excited to introduce a group of  patients to the exhilarating world of virtual reality at such a signicant stage in their lives.ldquoThis important research will help us better understand the benefits of using VR and identy future interventions which may improve the quality of le of patients receiving palliative care.ldquoThe patients loved it. They were thrilled by the experience.ldquoOne family member said it was the first time that her mother had smiled in months.ldquoIt was wonderful to see the immediate impact on iniduals.

title: dunbar-teenagers-role-alongside-300-star-gerard-butler-in-new-movie
story: Lewis Dean is already recognisable from big hits such as T Trainspotting and Outlaw King and is now playing the lead characterrsquos son in new film The Vanishing.The movie is based on the true story of three lighthouse keepers at Flannan Isle in Scotland who mysteriously disappeared without a trace in .It was filmed in Port Logan, Galloway, on the west coast.ldquoIt was a really fun experience, said Lewis, .ldquoEveryone was really nice to me on set, and I got to play Gerard Butlerrsquos son which was amazing.ldquoHe was great, and even told my dad that I was talented and a tough cookie after a long dayrsquos filmingLewis, from Meikle Park Road, Dunbar, joined an acting group when the family still lived in Paisley ndash Gerard Butlerrsquos home town ndash with his two brothers.All three children now have an agent, and Lewis and brother Brandon starred together in Outlaw King, making up two of the four children picked for the production.ldquoSome people at school have asked for selfies and things with me, though I donrsquot really talk about it too much, said LewisldquoHersquos very modest added mother Karen.ldquoWersquore so unbelievably proud of him. To see him on the red carpet with all these famous actors was surreal.The Vanishing is out in cinemas now after premiering at the Glasgow Film Festival in February.

title: plan-to-launch-new-radio-station-for-dunbar
story: Dunbar on Air will link up with Dunbar Online, a Facebook page focusing on the happenings in the town, in a bid to ldquoprovide a truly local radio service for Dunbar and the surrounding townships, villages and hamlets.Andrew Morris, who created East Lothian FM, which would go on to become Radio Saltire, is at the heart of the proposals and gave a presentation to the townrsquos community council.Mr Morris said: ldquoIt struck me that perhaps the people of Dunbar and environs could do with a radio station.ldquoI started Dunbar Online ndash it followed Heart of Dunbar, which had to close down and they had , members.ldquoDunbar Online has not been going two years and we have in excess of , people.ldquoWhen you look at the population of Dunbar as a whole, it is a hell of a percentage.ldquoThe plan is for Dunbar On Air and the site of Dunbar Online to be a unique partnership.Mr Morris told members he was in contact with OSCRabout setting up Dunbar On Air as a SCIO .He said: ldquoIrsquove got a lot of support and know quite honestlywe do it properly it will be a big asset to the town.ldquoInitially, it will be broadcasting on the internet only and the signal will be available anywhere in the worldyou have got a broadband service.In-house training will be provided at the station, which will be run entirely by volunteers. The station will also offer work experience opportunities for anyone looking to start a career in the media.As well as music, the station will promote local good causes and encourage involvement from schools, charities, clubs and other organisations.Mr Morris described Dunbar on Air as ldquoa small, honest, beautully formed community radio station ndash and one that will never pretend to be something it isnrsquot.Community councillors welcomed the idea while askingpremises had been identied for the stationrsquos base, which they have not.Mr Morris said there were certain things he was looking for, including wheelchair accessibility and   access.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the community council, was among those impressed with the idea.She said: ldquoI think it sounds hugely exciting. It has to potential to fill some really interesting gaps.ldquoI think we would like to stay close to this as a project.

story: The selling price on average of a property in the county is  per cent up on last year for the January to March period, with the average price now at pound,.Another added benefit for sellers is the increase in speed of selling times, which is now on average  days ndash two days faster than last year.Jamie Fraser-Davidson, business analyst as ESPC, said that ldquocontinuing uncertainty over Brexit had deterred some buyers and there was an increasing number of properties coming to market.But he added: ldquoAverage selling prices are continuing to increase year-on-year, indicating that buyer confidence hasnrsquot been impacted signicantly.

title: tims-tales-markle-and-saint-andrew
story: THERE is a legend attached to a small rocky outcrop at Markle, which is close to present-day East Linton.The legend tells us it was from this location that the Pictish King Angus II saw an x-shaped cross in the sky in AD  during the Battle of Athelstaneford.This was said to be a miracle sent by St Andrew, and was foretold to the king in a dream. A local tradition claims that the name Markle is actually a corruption of the word miracle, a reference to this legendary intervention of the saint on that day.This event is now seen as the lsquobirth of the Scottish flagrsquo, the Saltire thereafter becoming the flag of Scotland the tale is well told by the Scottish Flag Trust in the doocot by Athelstaneford Kirk, which has been wonderfully adapted into the Flag Heritage Centre.But why was it St Andrew who came to the aid of the Picts and Scots on that day and not, say, St Columba  The answer to this question may begin in a ,-year-old crypt in Northumberland.This crypt lies underneath the abbey of Hexham, a town in northern England. The crypt is an amazing survival from Anglo-Saxon times, built in the seventh century, more than  years before the Battle of Athelstaneford is said to have taken place.The crypt was part of a monastery built on the orders of the then abbot Wilfrid and it had a special purpose.Wilfrid was a passionate devotee of St Andrew. He had travelled to Rome and ed with a relic connected to the saint. Christianity at this time had not yet fully established its dominance, and Wilfrid was determined to create a great Christian holy site to encourage the spread of his faith.And what better way to do this than use a relic of St Andrew, an Apostle of Jesus himself So he established St Andrewrsquos monastery at Hexham in AD , and in the crypt below there was a shrine, in which the relic of the saint was kept.Pilgrims began to flock to the site and, although small, the design of the crypt gave an intense religious experience.The entrance was by the high altar of the church, with dark passageways for the pilgrims to file towards and pay homage to the relic of St Andrew.Even today, the now-empty shrine has the atmosphere of a sacred inner sanctum. The ancient feel of it is added to by the fact it was constructed with stones taken from abandoned Roman buildings, as Hexham is close to Hadrianrsquos Wall and the Roman garrison town of Corbridge.But what is the connection with the miracle at Markle The connection begins with Wilfridrsquos successor Acca, who became the abbot of St Andrewrsquos in Hexham in AD . He had travelled with Wilfrid and shared his devotion to St Andrew. It is said Acca acquired his own relics of St Andrew and added them to the collection at Hexham.But Acca the abbot was an evangelising monk. In AD , he left Hexham and journeyed beyond the old crumbling Roman wall and further north.It was around this time that East Lothian became part of Northumbria. But the kingdom beyond the seawas the land of the Picts.The story tells us that Acca met with the Pictish king Angusat a place called Kilrymont in Fe. Here, we are told, Acca gave the Christian Pictish leader some relics of St Andrew he had taken from Hexham and urged the king to create a new centre of Christian pilgrimage for the saint.From the limited historical accounts available, it does seem that it was indeed around this time that the religious site of St Andrews in Fe was established, at the place previously called Kilrymont.Further evidence of this is the amazing St Andrews Sarcophagus, which was discovered at St Andrews in the early th century. It can now be seen in the cathedral museum, where it is described as ldquoone of the finest examples of early medieval sculpture in Europe. It dates from the mid-s and was almost certainly commissioned by Angus for his own burial. He died in AD .And so the veneration of St Andrew in Scotland had begun well before the miracle at Markle, with King Angus resting at St Andrews in his magnicent sarcophagus. No wonder, then, when a later King Anguswas in need of ine intervention in AD , the saint he prayed to was St Andrew, who is then said to have replied in such a legendary, dramatic fashion.Here is the connection between the crypt at Hexham and the miracle seen at Markle: the relics of St Andrew brought to Fe which began the Scottish attachment to the saint may well have been part of the Hexham collection.But wait a minute! Thatrsquos not the story I have always been told when I go to St Andrews. The oft-told legend is that it was St Rulewho brought the relics to Fe in the fourth century. He was the bishop of the Greek city of Patras, where St Andrew was crucied.The story tells us he had a dream in which he was told that the relics of the saint, which he was the custodian of, were in danger and he must set sail with them. The dream told him that wherever he was shipwrecked, there the relics would find their new home.After months at sea, his ship was wrecked at Kilrymont in Fe. And so he established a new shrine and re-named the place St Andrews. No mention of a Northumbrian abbot, or relics from Hexham in this story!What are we to believe  There is often a haze between history and legend and they sometimes meet in a place too misty for us to see. Historical truth can be an elusive creature. You think you have grasped it when suddenly it slips away, leaving you searching once again. And sometimes a lost historical truth is to be found hidden in a legend.In the tale of St Andrewrsquos relics, history will side with the abbot, I suspect, but the romanticised and dramatic tale of St Rule has become the more popular and well-known explanation.But the reason for this is another story in itself.With thanks to Anna Blair, whose tale lsquoSaint and Saltirersquo inspired my research into this story.

title: eight-councils-allocate-66m-for-redevelopment-of-former-ravenscraig-steelworks-site
story: The eight councils involved have agreed to allocate an additional pound million for the Ravenscraig Infrastructure Accessproject.City Deal cash, along with an additional pound. million from North Lanarkshire Council, will be used to upgrade roads from the M at Motherwell through Ravenscraig to the M at Eurocentral and onward past Airdrie on a new link road to the A south of Cumbernauld.The transport infrastructure project, part of the wider Pan-Lanarkshire Orbital Corridor, is vital to the overall development of the Ravenscraig site, according to councillors.They estimate the revised proposals for redeveloping Ravenscraig could create more than , jobs and boost the economy by pound million a year.: The Glasgow City Council staff paid more than pound, last yearAt  hectares, Ravenscraig is one of Europes largest brownfield regeneration sites and accounts for % of the Glasgow City Regions vacant and derelict land.Ravencraig Ltds new masterplan for the area will be considered by the council in the coming weeks and includes proposals for , houses, five primary schools, a town park and more than ,sq m of office, industrial and retail space.Paul Kelly, depute leader of North Lanarkshire Council, said: "The regeneration of Ravencraig is of major strategic and economic importance to North Lanarkshire and the wider area."The pound million Pan-Lanarkshire Orbital project represents the biggest single roads and infrastructure investment in North Lanarkshires history, and our focus must be on those projects that will attract investment to the area and be of the greatest economic benefit to our communities."Channelling our resources into creating a first-class infrastructure at Ravenscraig will bolster future investment from the private sector to create homes, businesses and job opportunities - potentially creating , jobs and generating pound million in Gross Value Addedfor the local economy."Its vital that we focus on those projects that offer the beston investment for our communities, our economy and for the future of North Lanarkshire."Speaking on BBC Good Morning Scotland, Mr Kelly added: "Theres been huge delays over the years but I really feel today is a historic day - its the biggest investment well ever see in our infrastructure and it will lead to the transformation of the Ravenscraig site."Over the last two years we have been driving this as best we can to try to transform it and to deliver on what the people of Motherwell and the wider area want on the site."Scottish Secretary David Mundell, said: "This is very welcome news and it is great to see good progress being made to the Glasgow City Region Deal.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages"The UK Government has committed more than pound million to the deal with an ambitious goal of creating jobs and opportunities and stimulating long-lasting growth for local communities."This project has the potential to transform Ravenscraig and will help to attract signicant private sector investment to bring new homes and businesses to the site."The UK Government is funding vital projects right across Scotland and to date have committed more than pound. billion to City Region and Growth Deals."Scottish Government Infrastructure Secretary Michael Matheson said: "The Scottish Government has committed to invest pound million in the Glasgow City Region Deal in pursuit of long-term, sustainable economic growth."I am pleased to see North Lanarkshire Council and the wider Glasgow City Region continue to drive this deal forward and work together in the best interests of the regional economy."

title: Iain Macwhirter  As May goes down for the third time  the road to Brexit just got a whole lot longer
story: The Prime Minister has behaved asshe had a thumping Commons majority when in fact she is a minority leader of an unstable coalition. Even after the Damascene conversion of arch-Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, who used to described her deal as ldquovassalage, her final attempt to get a stripped-down Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament failed on Friday by a substantial majority. You have to give May full marks for her consistency: everything she touches turns to dust, even her own resignation.But thatrsquos by the by. As everyone has been saying: we are where we are. And where we are is extremely uncomfortable. Brexiters are gearing up to have a belly laugh at the opposition MPs, who will do their best throughout the coming week to find a compromise. Who do they think they are  Playing at being a provisional government  ldquoItrsquos like allowing the whelk stall to be run by the whelks, according to the Tory MP Sir Bill Cash. Butno-one  is able to run the eponymous stall, then all power to the whelks.Last weekrsquos indicative votes suggested that MPs are broadly in favour of a Brexit that keeps Britain in the EUrsquos economic loop while leaving the political institutions. Curiously, the SNP, who have been arguing for soft Brexit in two white papers and an election manesto, decided not to vote for the ious options, even the Norway model that they have long extolled. The SNP did, however, vote for the proposal from the Labour MP Margaret Beckett for a confirmatory ballot, and this option got the largest number of votes, much to everyonersquos surprise. This must be a serious possibility now that Parliament has failed to resolve the Brexit conundrum.However, this is not a Peoplersquos Vote as some have styled it. A confirmatory vote is not a rerun of the  referendum, but strictly a chance for voters to give their views on whatever deal Parliament agrees . The Kyle Wilson Amendment originally envisaged putting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal to a popular vote, assuming it was passed by Parliament. However, this confirmatory referendum might be dficult to schedule because it could collide with three other elections: a Tory leadership election, the European elections and a General Election. Brenda from Bristol will be in despair.EvenMPs fail to come up with a working compromise, they can still block a no-deal Brexit. The majority against leaving the EU without a deal is overwhelming. This means May, or her successor, will have to go cap-in-hand to Brussels in the next few days and request another, longer delay to Article . This would mean Britain participating in the European elections in May, which excites the Independent Group of Tory and Labour rebels, but is looked upon with dread by the main parties. Brussels too is worried about populist contagion spreading to other EU countries like Italy, but they are legally bound to make British participation a condition of any further extension to AVoter wrath, particularly in Labourrsquos leave constituencies, could lead to a dramatic revival of Nigel Faragersquos Ukip, or worse. The Svengali behind the  Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, is gearing up for the fight and reportedly suggesting a new party to fight for the right to leave. ldquoTell them again is the favoured slogan. The European elections might themselves turn into a kind of second referendum on Brexit.The Tories will presumably have a new leader by then, since Theresa May will surely go now there is to be the long extension she has resolutely opposed. Mind you, it is impossible to guess the Prime Ministerrsquos thought processes. She said she would goher withdrawal deal passed on Friday. But her gambit didnrsquot work. Even the opportunity to dispense with Mayrsquos services was not sufficient inducement for the Democratic Unionist Party to come on board. The joke doing the rounds last week was that she tried to fall on her sword and missed.But these things have a momentum of their own, and the Tory leadership election has already begun. Boris Johnson is the narrow frontrunner, but that could change. He might win the membership, but under Tory rules the parliamentary party has to agree the two candidates put to a postal ballot. The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: scottish-greens-leader-backs-pro-indy-pact-with-snp-at-holyrood-election
story: Maggie Chapman said such an arrangement was ldquocertainly possible, but added that her party would need to go into any discussions with the SNP knowing what they would not give up ldquoat any cost.However Pamela Nash, chief executive of the pro-UK Scotland in Union, said:ldquoVoters wonrsquot take kindly to a pro-independence stitch-up. The Scottish Greens have given up fighting to build a greener world, and now just want to build a more ided world by helping their SNP bosses.ldquoThe pro-independence parties will never stop campaigning for a isive second independence referendum, and they will use every single vote for them as an excuse to pursue the break up of the UK.The SNP and the Greens command a pro-independence majority at Holyrood, but senior Nationalists believe there is no possibility of a second referendum before .Allies of First Minister Nicola Sturgeon believe her party and the Greens will have make an explicit pitch to voters at the next election on indyref and use any victory as leverage with the UK Government.However, although both parties work closely together at Holyrood - the Greens have helped pass recent Budgets - they fight elections separately.The Greens rarely contest first-past-the-post contests for the Scottish Parliament, but they fought Edinburgh Central in  and won , votes.SNP insiders believed this decision was key to Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson taking the seat with a  majority.SNP MP Tommy Sheppard last week called for the Greens not to field a candidate in this seat: ldquoI appreciate itrsquos a big ask and I donrsquot think the Greens should do it in all circumstances.He added: ldquoWhat is the point in spending time and activist effort fighting a seat that you know you are not going to winthere is a serious and real chance of the Tories getting it because you split the vote Both parties also chased pro-independence votes on the regional lists at the last Holyrood election, with the Greens winning six seats and the SNP securing another four MSPs.Chapman, who along with Patrick Harvie is one of two Scottish Green partyrsquos co-conveners, is also sympathetic to joint working.Asked by this newspaper whether there could be an electoral pact or common understanding between the parties in , she said:ldquoIt is certainly possible. It is not something I would ever want us to rule out.She explained: ldquoWe would need to go into any of those discussions very clear of what it is we would be prepared to concede, what certain things would be our things that we would not give up at any cost.Asked whether it would be an attractive planit were toa pro-independence majority, she replied: ldquoFor me, I think it would be.In the wake of the  independence referendum, SNP MSPs backed pro-independence parties contesting the general election as either a "Yes Alliance" or a "Scotland Alliance".Leaked emails from that time showed Edinburgh Pentlands MSP Gordon MacDonald writing:"The next round is GE [General Election] . What about getting agreement with Greens, SSP, etc and stand as YES Alliance  The unionist vote would split between Labour, Tory  Libdem. We would do decidedly better than the small numbers of MPs we got elected last time.Joan McAlpine, another SNP MSP, was also revealed to have responded: "I was thinking along the same lines.An SNP spokesperson said: "The SNP contests every seat in every Scottish election, and we are always prepared to work constructively with other parties in Scotlandrsquos best interests.ldquoAt the next Holyrood election we will work hard to win as many seats as possible - in the hope that people put their trust in the SNP to stand up for their interests as Scotlands government."

title: iain-macwhirter-theresa-mays-zugzwang-means-a-long-hot-summer-of-indecision-on-brexit
story: What I didnt foresee is that Theresa May would still be in office after being forced to go to Brussels, twice, to beg for an extension to A. Not only was this a national humiliation, and a breach of promise, it has cost nearly pound.bn in No Deal preparations that had to be cancelled.Whatever happened to ldquoNo Deal is Better than a Bad Deal  Or the PMs insistence that holding European elections would be ldquoutterly unacceptable. Has a prime minister ever in history been so wrong so often and yet remained in office  I cant think of one. Theresa Mays staying power is formidable and has become a political force in itself. They used to say that, after a nuclear war, the only ones left would be cockroaches and the indestructible chanteuse, Cher. But Theresa May will still be there too, lecturing insect le on the merits of her Withdrawal Agreement.While she remains in office, nothing can really change. Indeed, the six month stay of execution on Brexit, awarded by the European Union last week, almost guarantees that nothing will change. The pressure is off. Negotiations with Labour over the customs union will surely stall. Brussels wont reopen the Withdrawal Agreement and neither will the DUP and Tory hard liners accept it. Theresa May is still blocking a Peoples Vote, about which Jeremy Corbyn is anyway distinctly cool.The European Elections are going to be an unavoidable nightmare for both the big parties. The Tories will suffer mass defections from disgruntled No Dealers. Labour will likely be torn apart over its manesto. The membership will want to include a Peoples Vote, which many Labour MPs, especially in northern English seats, will bitterly oppose.The new independent party, Change UK, will try to syphon of disgruntled Labour and Tory Remain voters, and could do quite well. Six million peopled have signed the parliamentary petition calling for Article  to be Revoked and they will want to turn the European elections into a proxy referendum. But the Tiggers will be fighting for votes with the Liberal Democrats and the Greens.One consolation is that the Brexit right is split also. Under Nigel Farage, Ukip came out top in the  EU elections and even won a seat in Scotland. On Friday, Mr Farage, launched his own rival political vehicle, the Brexit Party, following Ukips lurch to the Tommy Robinson far right.Thats going to be confusing for Leavers because Ukip is an established political brand. But it was essentially the Nigel Farage party, so it seems likely that his new Brexit Party could succeed in being the natural destination for hard Brexiteers. By the same token, moderate Tories will not want to touch anything led by Nigel Farage and will probably not vote at all.The one party which should do well hands down in the European elections is the SNP. Nicola Sturgeon will happily hoover up the independence and Remain votes. Labour has stalled badly in Scotland under Richard Leonard, and the Tories are indelibly tarnished by the behaviour of Theresa May and the Brexit right. Were the six Scottish MEPs to be elected on first past the post, the SNP might well have swept the board come May rd. But the European elections are conducted under a strict version of PR, so the SNP target will probably be to increase from two seats to three.After the European Elections, Theresa May, assuming she is still there , will presumably try to put her deal to parliament for a fourth time, or seek to have the Withdrawal Deal ratied by other procedural means, given that the Speaker has blocked a fourth Meaningful Vote. This will almost certainly fail, and a war-torn parliament will collapse into the long summer recess with ill-disguised relief.Nothing ever happens in Brussels over the Summer months, so discussions with Europe will stall, and in the autumn the EU will be pre-occupied with installing a new President of the European Council, replacing Donald Tusk, and a new President of the European Commission, replacing Jean Claude Juncker. This discontinuity means Brexit is in danger of falling into black hole of indecision. Europe is fed up with Britains Brexit psychodrama, and just want us to go away.Back in the UK, the run up to the latest Brexit deadline on Halloween, st October , will be by the UK party conferences. Both Labour and the Conservatives will be hopelessly ided. There will be harsh words in Labour between supporters of Mr Corbyns managed Brexit and supporters of a Peoples Vote who constitute the majority of Labour activists, especially the younger ones.The Tories will be even more ided at their party conference in October. The pro-Brexit representatives of the Tory grass roots will have their first opportunity to vent their collective frustration at the leadership, and Theresa May in particular. Andshe still tries to promote her deal, which is loathed by the hard Brexit Tory membership, she will be roasted by representatives who are in a state of incipient rebellion.The PM will almost certainly come out of the Tory conference having had to harden her Brexit negotiating position against the customs union compromise. Liam Fox the International Trade Secretary, has told the Tory backbench  Committee that a customs union is incompatible with Brexit and that Britain would be ldquostuck in the worst of both worlds.With her options closed off, and with the Halloween deadline approaching, Theresa May will be left trying to run down the clock as before. Presumably parliament will again intervene to vote against hard Brexit. So the PM may have to go back to Brussels, cap in hand, on November st asking for another extension. Brussels will hum and haw about this, and no doubt Emanuel Macron and Angela Merkel will continue their bad-cop-good-cop routine, before stling their giggles and giving the UK yet another stay of execution.This time it might be permanent because the May government would surely fall, and there would be a general election. I know that I said as much last time, but there must be a limit to Theresa Mays ability to struggle on in the face adversity. The DUP and the hard Brexiteers of the ERG are incorrigible.She cannot get her Withdrawal Deal through parliament and she cannot strike a deal with Labour without destroying her own party. In Chess this is called a Zugzwang, when the king has to make a move, even though every option makes the situation worse. But in politics as in chess, you cant do nothing indefinitely.

title: Marianne Taylor  Time to be more Zenlike when our Scottish banknotes are refused
story: First there was the matter of the pound price tag for two ndash TWO! ndash doughnuts. The tennis coach and mother of Wimbledon champs Andy and Jamie Murray must already have been regretting the decision not to go to Greggs for her sugar fix when she handed over her Bank of Scotland tenner only to be told by the cashier that the shop accepted only ldquoBritish notes.Read more: Judy Murrays Scottish banknote refused in London bakeryAs anyone who has read Ms Murrayrsquos excellent book outlining how she set her sons on the road to sporting greatness through sheer determination will know, Judy is not a woman who takes no for an answer. And, as her quarter of a million Twitter followers will attest, only tennis ranks above her love of cakes. So, although she didnrsquot elaborate on the outcome of the altercation, I can only imagine Ms Murray volleyed back as good as she got and ended up persuading the shop to accept Euros, groats and Monopoly money as well as Scottish cash.The tweet got so much traction because most Scots know and understand exactly how this interaction goes, just how grim and maddening it is no matter how many times yoursquove experienced it. These days many of us feel much more confident in our skins as Scots and are able to consider and reconcile our relationship with our English neighbours in more mature and expansive ways than ever before. But you still canrsquot escape the deep, primeval humiliation of having your money refused. And although this refusing is often down to ignorance rather than malice, especially in London, where so many of those who work in shops, restaurants and cafes are from overseas and donrsquot even know what a Scottish note is ndash why would they  - itrsquos something we Scots just canrsquot seem to get over. I include myself in this. Irsquove lived in London twice and looking back I used Scottish notes to symbolise and conflate the many dferent frustrations I felt with le in the metropolis.Read more: Why Scottish banknotes can be rejectedI could have given Basil Fawlty a run for his money as I ponticated to teenage shop assistants and foreign taxi drivers about ldquolegal tender and ldquoanti-Scottish discrimination, eventually admitting to myself that I found the ranting enjoyable, a form of stress relief, regardless of whether I succeeded in forcing my money upon them or not.Irsquom ashamed to admit now that I used to keep a Scottish tenner specically for the purpose of having a good rammy with the landlord of one of my local pubs. I suspect he enjoyed it just as much as I did, not least because hersquod never miss an opportunity to bring up the old clicheacute about Scots being tight. To give him his due, Irsquod usually get a wink and a free drink, too.The irony of all this, of course, is the fact that the banknotes so many of us defend to the end at cash desks all over England, day in, day out, are not legal tender at all. Not even in Scotland, as it turns out, where only coins have legal weight. According to the Bank of England, both coins and Bank of England notes are legal tender south of the border, with anything  a ldquomatter of agreement between the parties involved. This means each and every one of those painful refusals was legitimate, every ldquoput that in your pipe and smoke it, pal righteous speech made by you was nonsense. I found this out during my second stint in London, changing tack from rants around legality to arguments based on how petty and ldquohurtfultheir actions were. I had more luck with that.Read more: Judy Murrays Scottish banknote refused in London bakeryFormer Lib Dem Scottish Secretary Alistair Carmichael - remember him  - apprently plans to introduce a bill to the House of Commons that would oblige businesses to accept Scottish banknotes as payment. The current incumbent in the job, David Mundell, tried and failed to do something similar in .Other than the fact Parliament probably has more pressing concerns right now, surely this is simply a case of too little too late  With most of us using debit cards and contactless payments these days ndash only three in  transaction now use notes and coins, a figure expected to halve over the next decade - itrsquos clear the days of carrying banknotes of any sort are numbered: the cashless society is within swiping distance. Sweden, the first country to use the banknote back in , is expected to be the first to go completely cashless in .Read more: Why Scottish banknotes can be rejectedMaybe the time has finally come for Scots to stop fighting the good fight  Next time someone refuses your Scottish note, remain Zenlike. ldquoHow could I have been so silly  you will smile as you bring out your contactless card, resisting the urge to scream ldquoitrsquos legal tender, you ignoramus!. Not as much fun, granted, but so much better for the blood pressure.

title: former-yes-scotland-chief-says-its-2014-currency-policy-was-disastrous
story: Dennis Canavan insisted plans to share the pound in a currency union left the Yes side as a ldquohostage to fortune.It comes amid ongoing splits within the SNP over its latest proposals to keep using the pound after independence, before eventually moving to a new currency.Mr Canavan, the former chairman of Yes Scotland, told the BBCrsquos Good Morning Scotland: ldquoWe ought to be honest enough and humble enough to admit that mistakes were made.ldquoThe currency thing, for example, turned out to be disastrous. I mean you cannot have a currency union with another partner unless the other partner agrees to that currency union.ldquoSo it was a hostage to fortune, it was giving our opponents - our unionists opponents - a veto over the policy, so that was a mistake.ldquoI think that lessons have been learned now, that wersquove got to come up with a better currency option and Irsquom glad to see that support is growing and seems to be accepted now within members of the Scottish Government [for] the idea of an independent currency in Scotland.Mr Canavan urged Nicola Sturgeon to call another independence referendum before the next Holyrood elections in , but said he could understand her caution.

title: in-our-view-like-it-or-not-councils-need-cash-and-we-have-to-find-a-solution
story: However, one thing is clear ndash Scotland needs an urgent rethink of how best to fund our local authorities.They provide basic services essential for people across all sections of society, both rich and poor, not just those down on their luck with nowhere  to turn. Without the array of council services that many of us probably take for granted, the quality of le we are used to and the facilities we enjoy would be drastically dferent. Unfortunately, what may sound like fiction now could become realitynothing changes. Council leaders are already complaining that their resources are completely stretched, and their cupboards are bare.It is welcome to see such emphasis on the need for a rethink and a cash leline for local government in this latest report by Unison as well as previous proposals by Cosla and others. Even financial watchdog Audit Scotland last year acknowledged the reduction in funding for councils as a problem.What is worth noting is that solving the issue cannot simply be hinged on bumping up taxes for those earning the most. Everyone must take responsibility and acknowledge they may have to do more on less, pay more, wait a bit longer or do without until councils can get back on their feet.Taxing residents can only go so far to solve local authorities issues, and, whether you agree with them or not, the ideas offered up in this report should be the starting point for serious discussion on how we fix council funding troubles.

title: notre-dame-ad-campaign-to-stop-girls-school-letting-in-boys
story: Parents of pupils attending Notre Dame in Glasgow are taking action after a consultation was launched over its future.Some say they are against the call to make the Downhill secondary single sex. Notre Dame High School Parent Council will today launch an advertising campaign in Glasgow.Read more:Notre Dame: As campaigners call for it to enrol boys for the first time, we go inside Scotlands only all-girl state schoolA billboard van will tour the city with a sign that reads: ldquoKeep Notre Dame High School a positive choice for Glasgowrsquos girls.Michelle Watt, chairwoman of the parent council, said there was an overwhelming feeling against the move to making the school mixed sex.She said: ldquoThe ad is to show the strength of feeling many parents have about wanting to keep the school as a positive choice for families.ldquoFor more than  years the school has opened its doors to girls from Pollokshields to Partick, from the west end to Easterhouse.ldquoThe school is almost full, with a roll currently made up of  per cent placing requests, showing that families are actively choosing to send their girls to benefit from its inclusive and girl-centric environment.Following campaigning from primary school parents in the catchment area, Glasgow City Council agreed to launch a public consultation last month.Three public meetings are also being held with the first one taking place at Notre Dame High School, in the west end, tomorrow.The consultation runs until Sunday, May .There are three options that can be commented on: keep the school as it is with the same catchment keep the school as it is with an increased catchment area change the school to allow boys.Ms Watt added: ldquoNotre Dame High is one of the top performing secondaries in Glasgow and is actively contributing to narrowing the attainment gap between the cityrsquos wealthiest and most deprived pupils.:Talking sense on Notre DameldquoMany girls are from our vibrant ethnic communities many have shared beliefs and many come from disadvantaged backgrounds.ldquoIt is important we keep their choice of education available and their voices heard.She added: ldquoAt a time when young women are still being disadvantaged because of their gender, this school is empowering them to reach their full potential.The historic Notre Dame High School was recently placed third in the top performing schoolsrsquo league table.

title: letters-be-grateful-for-the-wiser-heads-of-the-eu
story: Aswe have not had enough sunny uplands turning to soggy moorland. We still have Mr Lakin postulating that breaking from the EU will boost our international competitiveness, against every other single global estimate. The basis for his sage forecast is a tweet from the President of the United States. That is where we are today. Wersquore breaking from the worlds largest trading block on the back of a -character comment on social media, from Donald Trump no less.Itrsquos then backed up by saying the UK grew . per cent and . per cent industrially in February versus forecasted German stagnation. The fact that Germany exports more than it imports while the UK imports more than it exports might be a factor here.Based on my professional experience in manufacturing I can guarantee that any uptick in the UK economy is purely to down to front-loading of manufacturing for the impending shock of Brexit. The next stage, evenwe do not exit, will be a surprise contraction in manufacturing output as stock levels have soared this is unavoidable now as the process has started. The supply channels and warehouses are full. The more subtle impacts of wasted commercial investment in Brexit mitigation will echo through businesses for a long long time. The lost jobs down to business migration to the EU are gone forever. Thankfully this will probably peter out now.Irsquom not sure where Mr Lakin was in the early s after we soared like an eagle out of the three-day week, miners strike, power strikes, lorry driver strikes and pound devaluation. I can say with great certainty no one was soaring in Clydebank. We had unemployment at levels unseen since before the war. My own father was unemployed for eight years without break. The whole country was affected, whole families devastated.I have always said from the start that once the realities of Brexit were felt that you will be hard pushed to find anyone who will admit supporting this nonsense. That wave has now begun. We can be thankful for cooler heads in Westminster, some very lucky parliamentary arithmetic and to our great friends in the EU for helping us avoid a national catastrophe. My advice to Mr Lakin would be learn the lesson, be happy that cooler heads and smarter people like Donald Tusk have helped us avoid a national disaster.Donrsquot double down on your madness, it will just take the whole embarrassment of it a lot longer for it to be forgotten.Campbell Grant Kennedy,Kuehlergrund -, Heidelberg , Germany.IAN Lakin declares that the fact of the UK wishing to leave the EU is the fault of the EU, and the subsequent toing and froing of Theresa May is also its fault. He does not seem to have noticed that Mrs May cannot get the support from the Westminster Parliament to justy her actions.Britain wants the EU to change the rules, then leave the EU. It would be a very strange club where rules were changed by departing members it could also be that Mr Lakin does not wish to see the EU receive any money for the disruption caused by the UK.He based his view on how we survived the s, the minersrsquo strike and the three-day week perhaps the political parties were a wee bit better than we see today ndash Mrs Thatcher did not come along until .He quotes President Trump as an example in trading to be admired any support for a politician who wants another country to build a wall, with its money, and who splits families up in pursuit of that aim, is not one anyone should wish to emulate.Mr Lakin calls the EU a spent force, while the  members of the EU are laughing at the UK.Jim Lynch, Corstorphine Hill Crescent, Edinburgh.Read more: European elections : Why is the UK involved and what does it mean for Brexit IAIN Macwhirter, writing on Scotlandrsquos behalf not to the EU, our alleged trading partner, but to the  nation states among whom we do actually trade, condescends to explain to these countries the meaning of sovereignty in a modern world .Oddly enough his is just the sophisticated reasoning employed by the mandarins of Whitehall in their infamous secret memorandum ldquoSovereignty and the European Communities in which they referred to the loss of sovereignty in both foreign and domestic affairs that membership involved. That was in  when the Acquis Communautaire had only , pages of laws to be enforced. Does Mr Macwhirter know how many hundreds of thousands have been added in the last  years or how very few areas of our lives are now left free from EU control Notable among the instructions contained in this paper is the reminder of absolute confidentiality during the following  years. The sanguine assumption by Whitehall and presumption by the seminal EU was that after  years Britain would be so enmeshed in Brussels legislation that it would be virtually impossible to leave.Politicians and the media have been carefulnot to attribute unpopular laws to the European Commission, Lord Kerr has introduced a totally unnecessary Article to the EU Constitution and Tony Blairrsquos most brilliant propagandist has been devoting his activities since the referendum to keeping Britain in the EU.But a treaty can always be unilaterally abrogated and , as Mr Macwhirter claims, ldquowe realise that we have become a laughing stock across Europe, we may as well go ahead and earn its execration also by making a clean break and facing the consequences.Above all we must campaign for parliamentary representatives to acquaint themselves with at least some of the main themes of the European project and to consider Britainrsquos independence alongside our GDP. And the media ndash which includes newspapers ndash should at this crucial stage be prepared to offer unspun facts and fair comment.Mary Rolls, Castlegate, Jedburgh.

title: shintys-young-female-stars-forge-path-into-toughest-of-sports
story: But the sport is attracting more and more females who are keen to get stuck in.The number of women and girls picking up the caman ndash or shinty stick ndash has tripled over the past four years, with ladiesrsquo clubs springing up all over Scotland.ldquoGirls used to have to stop playing once they left school as there were no games for them, but now we can carry on and enjoy the sport just like the men, said Donna Mackenzie, Scotland player and youth coach.Like most people in the Highlands, Donna grew up watching the sport ndash but she also wanted to take part in the rough-and-tumble game.ldquoMy mum and dad played but my mum had to give it up as there were no womenrsquos teams.ldquoI played at school, and because there are now womenrsquos leagues, I was able to develop my game, play for my local club, Glenurquhart, and ended up playing for Scotland, said Donna, , from Muir of Ord.ldquoIrsquom shinty daft ndash itrsquos so much fun and all my friends play. The whole community turns out to watch us play.Read more: Saving the critically endangered ancient art of shinty stick makingDonna coaches at girlsrsquo shinty camps and goes into schools to encourage participation.ldquoThe girls are really keen when they see a female role model. There are so many more opportunities for women and girls to play shinty now with new teams cropping up all over the place. The skill levels are increasing and last year the womenrsquos Valerie Fraser Camanachd Cup final was televised on BBC Alba for the first time.Maree Mackenzie, , not only plays for Kinlochshiel Ladies but also played for the boysrsquo under- team last year and was selected for the North Select U, effectively the best lsquoboysrsquo in the north of Scotland. She now plays for the under- boysrsquo team and hopes to play for Scotland.ldquoI was really chuffed when I got player of the year out of all the boys and girls.Read more: Rule change sees children barred from shinty competitionsldquoWhen I started playing with the boys they were a bit unsure and resistant but as soon as they saw I could play, they welcomed me onto the team, said Maree, from Glenelg in Ross-shire.When she was growing up, her girl friends thought shinty was a boysrsquo game but Maree refused to give up ndash despite her head being split open by a shinty ball and needing stitches.ldquoItrsquos a tough sport with lots of bumps and bruises. Irsquove broken fingers and my hands arenrsquot the prettiest. Itrsquos a hard sport and you have to develop your skills and keep your fitness up, but I love it.Katie Macrae, , was one of the girls who pushed for Kinlochshiel Ladies to be set up two years ago.ldquoThere was no local womenrsquos club and I couldnrsquot play for the menrsquos team, so I would have had to give up shinty, she said.ldquoItrsquos a great sport that creates good bonds between players. Women should have the same opportunities in sport as men ndash itrsquos about time it was opening up more for us.Derek Keir, Chief Executive Officer of the Camanachd Association, said: ldquoWe are keen to develop opportunities in the womenrsquos game.ldquoWhen Kinlochshiel asked us to host an open meeting to gauge interest in creating a ladiesrsquo team, more than  people attended.ldquoWe also trained coaches and referees and appointed two shinty ambassadors, one of them female, to grow support in the school.Sandra MacRae, Kinlochshiel Secretary, said: ldquoShinty is a great sport for girls and women as it helps them be more confident. There are no other team sports for girls in our area ndash no football or netball.ldquoThey all get so much out of shinty. Irsquove seen shy girls transformed. It instills discipline, confidence and camaraderie. It also helps teenage girls realise that losing is not the end of the world. It encourages resilience.Shinty players and fans ndash both women and men ndash will be watching the final of the Tulloch Homes Camanachd Cup on Saturday  September at An Aird, Fort William.Folk-rock musician and broadcaster Gary Innes, a former Camanachd Cup winner and the trophyrsquos ambassador, said: ldquoItrsquos absolutely tremendous that womenrsquos shinty is flourishing and the standard is getting better every year.ldquoMore women and girls taking part will help the game survive in this current climate where there are so many other things competing for peoplersquos attention. Womenrsquos involvement will help the sport to grow and raise its profile.

title: first-glasgow-launch-new-state-of-the-art-buses-on-airport-service
story: The  new E city double decker buses built by Alexander Dennis in Falkirk will double the capacity on these popular services and the new vehicles will be in operation on the  service from Sunday, April th serving one of the busiest airports in the UK.The new vehicles come with luxury double padded seating, free G WIFI, USB charging points as well as new state-of-the-art wireless charging facilities on both the tables and seatbacks, luggage racks and most important of all, ultra-low emission Euro VI diesel engines.All  vehicles have also been fitted with the state-of-the-art SmartVision system, which replaces the traditional wing mirrors with a CCTV system fitted within the Driverrsquos cab to provide extra vision and safety. This system was originally trialled on the  services when the new vehicles were originally launched last October and now First Glasgow has extended the trial to all  of its Glasgow Airport Express service vehicles.The  service runs from Glasgow City Centre to the airport in as little as  minutes. This is one of the Glasgow operatorrsquos most popular services carrying over . million passengers annually and an openticket on this frequent service is just pound., available on the First Bus App, when you plan your journey in advance.The new buses went on display to the public at a special launch event with Capital FM presenter Garry Spence entertaining the crowd at George Square in Glasgow city centre on Saturday, April th prior to the  new vehicles going into active service.The event saw First Glasgow bring summer to the city centre early with giant deck chairs, prize giveaways and exclusive offers to celebrate their launch.Glasgow Airport staff were in attendance to mark the launch of these new premium vehicles as part of their on-going partnership with First Glasgow, along with Visit Scotland and Alexander Dennis.Mark Johnston, Managing Director at Glasgow Airport, said: ldquoWe are proud to welcome this latest First Bus fleet into operation and Irsquom really impressed with the new ADL E City model.ldquoAs well as vastly improving capacity, the double-deckers offer a number of fantastic customer experience enhancements. Irsquom sure our passengers who choose to sit in the upper deck level will also appreciate the elevated views these new models bring.ldquoThe First  Service provides vital connectivity between the airport and the city centre to millions of passengers each year and First Bus is to be congratulated for the signicant investment made to introduce this new fleet.Marie Connell, Business Development Manager at Alexander Dennis Limited, stated:ldquoI supported the launch of the initial Enviro fleet on the Glasgow Airport Express route in  and am delighted that we are taking our collaboration with First Glasgow on this popular route to a whole new level with these  new Enviro.ldquoFirst Glasgow gave us a challenging brief ndash low emission double decks, which meet the weight restrictions demanded of LEB compliant vehicles without compromising on passenger comfort.The premium interior specication of these low emission Enviros ensures that all passengers will enjoy a first-class passenger experience travelling to and from the airport.Glasgowrsquos largest operator has now invested over pound million in a total of  new ultra-low emission vehicles for Glasgow since October . This highlights First Glasgowrsquos continuing commitment to improving the quality of offering to its customers while at the same time playing its role in improving air quality in the city.Andrew Jarvis, Managing Director for First Glasgow, said: ldquoIt is exciting times for everyone at First Glasgow in being able to share these vehicles with the people of Glasgow and the rest of the world via our friends at Glasgow Airport. We have a great working relationship with the airport team and with these new state-of-the-art vehicles, we are providing their customers with a first-class experience on their journeys to and from the airport.ldquoThis investment marks the end of our second phase of new bus launches linked with the Glasgow Low Emissions Zoneand takes us a long way toward compliance for phase . We are delighted to have delivered such a vast range of service improvements to our customers since October last year and these latest buses are the next level for our premium express airport service. title: indiana-mayor-pete-buttigieg-joins-2020-democratic-presidential-race
story: ldquoI recognise the audacity of doing this as a Midwestern millennial mayor, he said to cheers of ldquoPete, Pete, Pete from an audience assembled in a former Studebaker car plant.ldquoMore than a little bold, at age , to seek the highest office in the land.:Donald Trump considers releasing lsquoillegal immigrantsrsquo in Democratic strongholdsIn the hours after his announcement, more than one million dollarsin donations poured in, said Lis Smith, speaking for the campaign.I just announced Im running for president of the United States. Join in and donateyou can. Its going to be an amazing ride and I cant wait to be on it with you all the way to the White House: https:t.co edZnUvfcI pic OTiYsAGRmdash Pete ButtigiegApril , The South Bend mayor, a Rhodes scholar and Afghanistan War veteran who has been essentially campaigning since January, has joined a dozen-plus rivals vying to take on President Donald Trump.ldquoThe forces of change in our country today are tectonic, he said.ldquoForces that help to explain what made this current presidency even possible. Thatrsquos why, this time, itrsquos not just about winning an election ndash itrsquos about winning an era.Mr Buttigieg willthis week to Iowa and New Hampshire, which hold the nationrsquos first nominating contests, to campaign as a fully fledged candidate now being taken more seriously.Over the past few months, Mr Buttigieg has appeared frequently on national TV news and talk shows and developed a strong social media following with his message that the country needs ldquoa new generation of leadership.Mr Buttigiegrsquos poll numbers have climbed.Some polls put him behind only Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders, who sought the partyrsquos nomination in , and former vice president Joe Biden, who has not yet said he is running.Mr Buttigiegrsquos campaign has raised more than seven million dollarsin the first three months of this year, a total eclipsed by Mr Sandersrsquos leading  million dollarsbut more than senators Elizabeth Warren, Amy Klobuchar and Cory Booker.ldquoRight now, itrsquos pretty fun, Mr Buttigieg said last month while visiting South Carolina , where he was met by larger-than-expected crowds.His challenge is finding a way to sustain the momentum over the long term and avoiding becoming a ldquoflavour of the month candidate.Scrutiny of his leadership in South Bend has increased, as has his criticism of vice president Mike Pence, who was Indianarsquos governor when Mr Buttigieg was in his first term as mayor.Mr Buttigieg would be the first openly gay nominee of a major presidential party he married his husband Chasten last year.He would be the first mayor to go directly to the White House.And he would be the youngest person to become president, turning  the day before the next inauguration, on January  .Theodore Roosevelt was  when he took office, while John F Kennedy was  and Bill Clinton .The campaign kickoff speech echoed themes that have resonated with voters during Mr Buttigiegrsquos exploratory phase.:The questions Americans are asking about BrexitHe talks often about how political decisions shape peoplersquos lives, including his own ndash from serving as a lieutenant in the navy reserve in , to being able to marry his husband and to not having to worry about how to pay for his fatherrsquos hospital bills after his fatherrsquos death this year.Mr Buttigieg also says the best way for Democrats to defeat Mr Trump may be to nominate a mayor experienced in helping to revive a Midwestern city once described as ldquodying, rather than a politician who has spent years ldquomarinating in Washington.He has criticised Mr Trumprsquos campaign slogan, Make America Great Again, saying the way to move the country forward is not to look backward or cling to an old way of le.ldquoTherersquos a myth being sold to industrial and rural communities: the myth that we can stop the clock and turn it back, he said.ldquoIt comes from people who think the only way to reach communities like ours is through resentment and nostalgia, selling an impossible promise of ing to a bygone era that was never as great as advertised to begin with.South Bend, which neighbours the University of Notre Dame, was hit hard by the decline of manufacturing, dating to the  closing of the Studebaker car plant that cost thousands of residents their jobs.The hulking, dilapidated factory loomed over the city for much of the past  years as what Mr Buttigieg called a daily reminder of South Bendrsquos past.Partially remodelled, it is now a mixed-use technology centre ndash and the setting for Mr Buttigiegrsquos announcement.The South Bend fire marshalrsquos office said the rally drew more than , inside and , outside.A steady stream of raindrops fell on speakers on the stage through the leaky roof.ldquoI like that hersquos young, said Tom Lacy, a -year-old retiree who came from Peoria, Illinois, for the event with his we Candy on their th wedding anniversary.ldquoHersquos so relatable. He doesnrsquot seem like a politician to me.ldquoThe contrast between him and our current president is unbelievable.Nausher Ahmad Sial, a -year-old developer from South Bend, said ldquowe need to try new blood.Mr Sial, who came to the US from Pakistan  years ago, said he has worked with Mr Buttigieg on development projects in the city and described the mayor as a ldquovery honest, very fair guy.

title: revealed-the-traits-we-want-our-childrens-friends-to-have
story: Researchers who carried out a detailed study found two thirds of parents are keen for their children to hang out with kids who work hard at school and three in  like those who take their homework seriously.The report also shows six in  are happytheir childrenrsquos friends do well at sports day and take part in extra-curricular sporting activities.And a further  per cent of mums and dads admitted they often go as far as making friends with the parents of the lsquonice kidsrsquo to ease the path of friendship.Image by StartupStockPhotos from Pixabay The study of , parents with kids under the age of  also revealed the top  traits most like to see in their childrens friends which include kindness, generosity and empathy.Other traits such as being ambitious, sporty and academic also made the list.Puffin commissioned the study to celebrate the launch of Diary of an Awesome Friendly Kid.Bestselling author Jeff Kinney said: ldquoThis survey shows that parents in the UK want their kids to have kind, empathetic friends.Rowley Jefferson, the main character in Diary of an Awesome Friendly Kid, seems a great match for what British parents are seeking in their childrenrsquos friends.ldquoHersquos kind, helpful and generous and it sounds like he would be high demand for playdates and sleepovers in the UK.ldquoRowley really enjoys being a kid and is in no rush to grow up too quick. I wish I had been more like him as a child.TOP  TRAITS PARENTS WANT THEIR CHILDRENrsquoS FRIENDS TO HAVE:. Kind. Helpful. Funny. Hard working. Generous. Empathetic. Confident. Protective. Take their homework seriously. Clever. Adventurous. Ambitious. Academic. Brave. Not too competitive. Doesnt take themselves seriously. Outdoorsy. Sporty. Cheeky. ToughThe study also found one in five parents feel strongly that their child should have one very best friend, preferring their child to have a wider friendship circle instead.Almost six in  parents admit they make more of an effort with the friends of their children they like, than those they donrsquot.The research indicates that parents do everything they can to encourage their own childrsquos popularity.More than half of British kids are treated to an average of three sleepovers a month, while six in  kids will enjoy a couple of day trips out with friends.And most children are lucky enough to have a friend round for tea every couple of weeks, as parents do everything they can to help their child carve out meaningful relationships.Image by Pexels from Pixabay Six in  parents also actively encourage their children to go out and about with their friends, and the average child will go to the park, join in on football or play at least four times a month.Parents also admit to making a huge effort whenever friends come round to the house ndash with  per cent buying lots of sweets and treats for the occasion and a further  per cent trying to engage the play date in conversation they think may be of interest.Letting the children do whatever they want, allowing them to stay up way past the usual bedtime and not telling them off for anything are among other ways parents try to be cool.
